1.verse: I give you thanks, O God of my father; I praise you, O God my savior! I will make known your name, refuge of my life;

2.verse: you have been my helper against my adversaries. You have saved me from death, and kept back my body from the pit, From the clutches of the nether world you have snatched my feet;

3.verse: you have delivered me, in your great mercy From the scourge of a slanderous tongue, and from lips that went over to falsehood; From the snare of those who watched for my downfall, and from the power of those who sought my life; From many a danger you have saved me,

4.verse: from flames that hemmed me in on every side; From the midst of unremitting fire,

5.verse: From the deep belly of the nether world; From deceiving lips and painters of lies,

6.verse: from the arrows of dishonest tongues. I was at the point of death, my soul was nearing the depths of the nether world;

7.verse: I turned every way, but there was no one to help me, I looked for one to sustain me, but could find no one.

8.verse: But then I remembered the mercies of the LORD, his kindness through ages past; For he saves those who take refuge in him, and rescues them from every evil.

9.verse: So I raised my voice from the very earth, from the gates of the nether world, my cry.

10.verse: I called out: O Lord, you are my father, you are my champion and my savior; Do not abandon me in time of trouble, in the midst of storms and dangers.

11.verse: I will ever praise your name and be constant in my prayers to you. Thereupon the LORD heard my voice, he listened to my appeal;

12.verse: He saved me from evil of every kind and preserved me in time of trouble. For this reason I thank him and I praise him; I bless the name of the LORD.

13.verse: When I was young and innocent, I sought wisdom.

14.verse: She came to me in her beauty, and until the end I will cultivate her.

15.verse: As the blossoms yielded to ripening grapes, the heart's joy, My feet kept to the level path because from earliest youth I was familiar with her.

16.verse: In the short time I paid heed, I met with great instruction.

17.verse: Since in this way I have profited, I will give my teacher grateful praise.

18.verse: I became resolutely devoted to her - the good I persistently strove for.

19.verse: I burned with desire for her, never turning back. I became preoccupied with her, never weary of extolling her. My hand opened her gate and I came to know her secrets.

20.verse: For her I purified my hands; in cleanness I attained to her. At first acquaintance with her, I gained understanding such that I will never forsake her.

21.verse: My whole being was stirred as I learned about her; therefore I have made her my prize possession.

22.verse: The LORD has granted me my lips as a reward, and my tongue will declare his praises.

23.verse: Come aside to me, you untutored, and take up lodging in the house of instruction;

24.verse: How long will you be deprived of wisdom's food, how long will you endure such bitter thirst?

25.verse: I open my mouth and speak of her: gain, at no cost, wisdom for yourselves.

26.verse: Submit your neck to her yoke, that your mind may accept her teaching. For she is close to those who seek her, and the one who is in earnest finds her.

27.verse: See for yourselves! I have labored only a little, but have found much.

28.verse: Acquire but a little instruction; you will win silver and gold through her.

29.verse: Let your spirits rejoice in the mercy of God, and be not ashamed to give him praise.

30.verse: Work at your tasks in due season, and in his own time God will give you your reward.

annotations.1: [1-12] A canticle of praise and thanks to God for delivering the author from slander, dangers, destruction, death, the nether world, and evil of every kind.
annotations.2: [12] After this verse the Hebrew text gives the litany of praise contained below. It is similar to Psalm 136. Though not found in any versions, and therefore of doubtful authenticity, the litany seems from internal evidence to go back to the time of Sirach
annotations.3: [13-30] An alphabetic canticle describing: a) the approach to wisdom through prayer, persistent study and instruction ( Sirach 51:13-17), purification from sin, enlightenment and ardent desire; b) the possession of wisdom ( Sirach 51:18-22). The author concludes with an urgent invitation to men to receive instruction in wisdom from him, and to live by it, because wisdom gives herself to those who seek her ( Sirach 51:23-26); and for their labor, God will reward them in the end ( Sirach 51:27-30). Cf Matthew 11:28; Eccl 12:14
annotations.4: [13] In the Greek of 13f there is an expansion introducing Solomon as the speaker. This deviates from the original author's intent. It reads: "Publicly, in my prayer, facing the temple, I asked for her."

1.verse: He does a kindness who lends to his neighbor, and he fulfills the precepts who holds out a helping hand.

2.verse: Lend to your neighbor in his hour of need, and pay back your neighbor when a loan falls due;

3.verse: Keep your promise, be honest with him, and you will always come by what you need.

4.verse: Many a man who asks for a loan adds to the burdens of those who help him;

5.verse: When he borrows, he kisses the lender's hand and speaks with respect of his creditor's wealth; But when payment is due he disappoints him and says he is helpless to meet the claim.

6.verse: If the lender is able to recover barely half, he considers this an achievement; If not, he is cheated of his wealth and acquires an enemy at no extra charge; With curses and insults the borrower pays him back, with abuse instead of honor.

7.verse: Many refuse to lend, not out of meanness, but from fear of being cheated.

8.verse: To a poor man, however, be generous; keep him not waiting for your alms;

9.verse: Because of the precept, help the needy, and in their want, do not send them away empty-handed.

10.verse: Spend your money for your brother and friend, and hide it not under a stone to perish;

11.verse: Dispose of your treasure as the Most High commands, for that will profit you more than the gold.

12.verse: Store up almsgiving in your treasure house, and it will save you from every evil;

13.verse: Better than a stout shield and a sturdy spear it will fight for you against the foe.

14.verse: A good man goes surety for his neighbor, and only the shameless would play him false;

15.verse: Forget not the kindness of your backer, for he offers his very life for you.

16.verse: The wicked turn a pledge on their behalf into misfortune, and the ingrate abandons his protector;

17.verse: Going surety has ruined many prosperous men and tossed them about like waves of the sea,

18.verse: Has exiled men of prominence and sent them wandering through foreign lands.

19.verse: The sinner through surety comes to grief, and he who undertakes too much falls into lawsuits.

20.verse: Go surety for your neighbor according to your means, but take care lest you fall thereby.

21.verse: Life's prime needs are water, bread, and clothing, a house, too, for decent privacy.

22.verse: Better a poor man's fare under the shadow of one's own roof than sumptuous banquets among strangers.

23.verse: Be it little or much, be content with what you have, and pay no heed to him who would disparage your home;

24.verse: A miserable life it is to go from house to house, for as a guest you dare not open your mouth.

25.verse: The visitor has no thanks for filling the cups; besides, you will hear these bitter words:

26.verse: "Come here, stranger, set the table, give me to eat the food you have!

27.verse: Away, stranger, for one more worthy; for my brother's visit I need the room!"

28.verse: Painful things to a sensitive man are abuse at home and insults from his creditors.

annotations.1: [1-20] Some practical maxims concerning the use of wealth. Give to a poor man ( Sirach 29:8, 9), lend to a needy neighbor, but repay when a loan falls due lest the lender's burden be increased ( Sirach 29:1-5) and his kindness abused ( Sirach 29:6- 7); through charity build up defense against evil ( Sirach 29:10-13). Go surety for your neighbor according to your means, but take care ( Sirach 29:20) not to fall, for the shameless play false and bring their protectors and themselves to misfortune and ruin ( Sirach 29:14-19).
annotations.2: [21-28] The man who provides his own basic needs of food, clothing and dwelling, and is content with what he has, preserves his freedom and self-respect ( Sirach 29:21-23). But if he lives as a guest, even among the rich, he exposes himself to insult and abuse ( Sirach 29:24-28)

1.verse: My son, if you have sinned, do so no more, and for your past sins pray to be forgiven.

2.verse: Flee from sin as from a serpent. that will bite you if you go near it; Its teeth are lion's teeth, destroying the souls of men.

3.verse: Every offense is a two-edged sword; when it cuts, there can be no healing.

4.verse: Violence and arrogance wipe out wealth; so too a proud man's home is destroyed.

5.verse: Prayer from a poor man's lips is heard at once, and justice is quickly granted him.

6.verse: He who hates correction walks the sinner's path, but he who fears the LORD repents in his heart.

7.verse: Widely known is the boastful speaker but the wise man knows his own faults.

8.verse: He who builds his house with another's money is collecting stones for his funeral mound.

9.verse: A band of criminals is like a bundle of tow; they will end in a flaming fire.

10.verse: The path of sinners is smooth stones that end in the depths of the nether world.

11.verse: He who keeps the law controls his impulses; he who is perfect in fear of the LORD has wisdom.

12.verse: He can never be taught who is not shrewd, but one form of shrewdness is thoroughly bitter.

13.verse: A wise man's knowledge wells up in a flood, and his counsel, like a living spring;

14.verse: A fool's mind is like a broken jar - no knowledge at all can it hold.

15.verse: When an intelligent man hears words of wisdom, he approves them and adds to them; The wanton hears them with scorn and casts them behind his back.

16.verse: A fool's chatter is like a load on a journey, but there is charm to be found upon the lips of the wise.

17.verse: The views of a prudent man are sought in an assembly, and his words are considered with care.

18.verse: Like a house in ruins is wisdom to a fool; the stupid man knows it only as inscrutable words.

19.verse: Like fetters on the legs is learning to a fool, like a manacle on his right hand.

20.verse: A fool raises his voice in laughter, but the prudent man at the most smiles gently.

21.verse: Like a chain of gold is learning to a wise man, like a bracelet on his right arm.

22.verse: The fool steps boldly into a house, while the well-bred man remains outside;

23.verse: A boor peeps through the doorway of a house, but a cultured man keeps his glance cast down.

24.verse: It is rude for one to listen at a door; a cultured man would be overwhelmed by the disgrace of it.

25.verse: The lips of the impious talk of what is not their concern, but the words of the prudent are carefully weighed.

26.verse: Fools' thoughts are in their mouths, wise men's words are in their hearts.

27.verse: When a godless man curses his adversary he really curses himself.

28.verse: A slanderer besmirches himself, and is hated by his neighbors.

annotations.1: [1-10] Under various figures, the consequences of sin are described as destructive of wealth, and even of bodily life, and deserving of death and a place in the depths of the nether world ( Sirach 21:2-4, 6a, 8-10). Through prayer, forgiveness can be sought ( Sirach 21:1), and through fear of the Lord, repentance is achieved ( Sirach 1:5, 6b).
annotations.2: [10] The path of sinners . . . nether world: eternal retribution is not yet proposed in this reference. It became clearly revealed through the teaching of Christ; cf Matthew 7:13, 14; 25:1-46; Luke 16:19-31
annotations.3: [11-28] The mind of the wise man is a fountain of knowledge ( Sirach 21:13, 15); his will is trained to keep the law ( Sirach 21:11); his words are gracious, valued, carefully weighed, sincere ( Sirach 21:16-17, 25-26); his conduct is respectful, cultured and restrained ( Sirach 21:20, 22-24). The fool's mind is devoid of knowledge and impenetrable to it ( Sirach 21:12, 14, 18, 19); his will rejects it ( Sirach 21:15); his talk is burdensome (16), his laughter unrestrained ( Sirach 21:20), his conversation shallow and meddlesome ( Sirach 21:25, 26); his conduct is bold and rude ( Sirach 21:22-24); his abuse of others redounds on himself ( Sirach 21:27-28)
annotations.4: [27] Adversary: this can be understood in the sense that, if a man curses one who led him into sin, he implicitly curses himself for having yielded to the sin; or in the sense that the enemy is the man's own sinful nature; or even in the sense that the enemy is the devil, since the Hebrew word used here is satan. Cf 1 Chron 21:1; Zechariah 3:2; 2 Peter 2:12, 13; Jude 1:9

1.verse: He who does so grows no richer; he who wastes the little he has will be stripped bare.

2.verse: Wine and women make the mind giddy, and the companion of harlots becomes reckless.

4.verse: He who lightly trusts in them has no sense, and he who strays after them sins against his own life.

3.verse: Rottenness and worms will possess him, for contumacious desire destroys its owner.

5.verse: He who gloats over evil will meet with evil, and he who repeats an evil report has no sense.

6.verse: Never repeat gossip, and you will not be reviled.

7.verse: Tell nothing to friend or foe; if you have a fault, reveal it not,

8.verse: For he who hears it will hold it against you, and in time become your enemy.

9.verse: Let anything you hear die within you; be assured it will not make you burst.

10.verse: When a fool hears something, he is in labor, like a woman giving birth to a child.

11.verse: Like an arrow lodged in a man's thigh is gossip in the breast of a fool.

12.verse: Admonish your friend - he may not have done it; and if he did, that he may not do it again.

13.verse: Admonish your neighbor - he may not have said it; and if he did, that he may not say it again.

14.verse: Admonish your friend - often it may be slander; every story you must not believe.

15.verse: Then, too, a man can slip and not mean it; who has not sinned with his tongue?

16.verse: Admonish your neighbor before you break with him; thus will you fulfill the law of the Most High.

17.verse: All wisdom is fear of the LORD; perfect wisdom is the fulfillment of the law.

18.verse: The knowledge of wickedness is not wisdom, nor is there prudence in the counsel of sinners.

19.verse: There is a shrewdness that is detestable, while the simple man may be free from sin.

20.verse: There are those with little understanding who fear God, and those of great intelligence who violate the law.

21.verse: There is a shrewdness keen but dishonest, which by duplicity wins a judgment.

22.verse: There is the wicked man who is bowed in grief, but is full of guile within;

23.verse: He bows his head and feigns not to hear, but when not observed, he will take advantage of you:

24.verse: Even though his lack of strength keeps him from sinning, when he finds the opportunity, he will do harm.

25.verse: One can tell a man by his appearance; a wise man is known as such when first met.

26.verse: A man's attire, his hearty laughter and his gait, proclaim him for what he is.

annotations.1: [5-16] An excellent commentary on the eighth commandment of the Decalogue, forbidding intemperance in speech through calumny, rash judgment, and detraction ( Sirach 19:5-6), and inculcating discreet silence in defense of self and of neighbor ( Sirach 19:7-11). Justice requires that an accused neighbor be given a hearing, and charity urges fraternal correction; both together fulfill the law of the Most High ( Sirach 19:12-16); cf Matthew 7:1-2; 18:15-16.
annotations.2: [17-26] True and false wisdom as here described are synonymous with virtue and vice, with the fulfillment of the law and the violation of it

1.verse: After him came NATHAN who served in the presence of David.

2.verse: Like the choice fat of the sacred offerings, so was DAVID in Israel.

3.verse: He made sport of lions as though they were kids, and of bears, like lambs of the flock.

4.verse: As a youth he slew the giant and wiped out the people's disgrace, When his hand let fly the slingstone that crushed the pride of Goliath.

5.verse: Since he called upon the Most High God, who gave strength to his right arm To defeat the skilled warrior and raise up the might of his people,

6.verse: Therefore the women sang his praises and ascribed to him tens of thousands. When he assumed the royal crown, he battled

7.verse: and subdued the enemy on every side. He destroyed the hostile Philistines and shattered their power till our own day.

8.verse: With his every deed he offered thanks to God Most High, in words of praise. With his whole being he loved his Maker and daily had his praises sung;

9.verse: He added beauty to the feasts and solemnized the seasons of each year With string music before the altar, providing sweet melody for the psalms

10.verse: So that when the Holy Name was praised, before daybreak the sanctuary would resound.

11.verse: The LORD forgave him his sins and exalted his strength forever; He conferred on him the rights of royalty and established his throne in Israel.

12.verse: Because of his merits he had as his successor a wise son, who lived in security:

13.verse: SOLOMON reigned during an era of peace, for God made tranquil all his borders. He built a house to the name of God, and established a lasting sanctuary.

14.verse: How wise you were when you were young, overflowing with instruction, like the Nile in flood!

15.verse: Your understanding covered the whole earth, and, like a sea, filled it with knowledge.

16.verse: Your fame reached distant coasts, and their peoples came to hear you;

17.verse: With song and story and riddle, and with your answers, you astounded the nations.

18.verse: You were called by that glorious name which was conferred upon Israel. Gold you gathered like so much iron, you heaped up silver as though it were lead;

19.verse: But you abandoned yourself to women and gave them dominion over your body.

20.verse: You brought dishonor upon your reputation, shame upon your marriage, Wrath upon your descendants, and groaning upon your domain;

21.verse: Thus two governments came into being, when in Ephraim kingship was usurped.

22.verse: But God does not withdraw his mercy, nor permit even one of his promises to fail. He does not uproot the posterity of his chosen one, nor destroy the offspring of his friend. So he gave to Jacob a remnant, to David a root from his own family.

23.verse: Solomon finally slept with his fathers, and left behind him one of his sons, Expansive in folly, limited in sense, REHOBOAM, who by his policy made the people rebel; Until one arose who should not be remembered, the sinner who led Israel into sin, Who brought ruin to Ephraim

24.verse: and caused them to be exiled from their land. Their sinfulness grew more and more,

25.verse: and they lent themselves to every evil,

annotations.1: [1-11] David, a youthful and fearless warrior, the favorite of all Israel, by defeating Goliath, the boastful Philistine giant, removed the people's disgrace and greatly strengthened their power ( Sirach 47:1-7). With his whole being he loved and praised God, and his devotion to divine worship led him to develop a liturgical cult. David fell into sin, but repenting, received pardon from God and the promise of an everlasting kingdom ( Sirach 47:8-11).
annotations.2: [12-24] Solomon, son and successor of David, inherited peace through his father's conquests. He built the magnificent temple of Jerusalem ( Sirach 47:12-13) and received from God the favor of unparalleled wisdom, through which he obtained great fame ( Sirach 47:14-17). Luxury and sensuality, however, brought disgrace upon him, and because of his oppressive burdens, he disposed the kingdom for division after his death ( Sirach 47:19-21, 23-24). Nevertheless God did not withdraw his promise of establishing his throne in the descendants of David ( Sirach 47:22)
annotations.3: [18] Cf 2 Sam 12:25 where Solomon is called Jedidiah, "beloved of the Lord." The same term is used of Israel in Jeremiah 11:15
annotations.4: [23] Expansive: the name Rehoboam means "the people is expansive," that is, widespread. The sinner: Jeroboam; cf 1 Kings 12:2, 20, 26-32
annotations.5: [ 47:25- 48:11] The prophetic ministry of Elijah amid widespread idolatry is here described as a judgment by fire ( Sirach 47:25-26). Through his preaching, miracles and vengeance against God's enemies within and without Israel, the prophet succeeded for a time in destroying idols and in restoring faith and the worship of the true God ( Sirach 48:2-8). His miraculous departure from this life gave rise to the belief that he did not die but would return before the end of the world to put an end to wrath and restore the tribes of Israel ( Sirach 48:9-11). Cf Matthew 17:9-13

1.verse: How different the man who devotes himself to the study of the law of the Most High! He explores the wisdom of the men of old and occupies himself with the prophecies;

2.verse: He treasures the discourses of famous men, and goes to the heart of involved sayings;

3.verse: He studies obscure parables, and is busied with the hidden meanings of the sages.

4.verse: He is in attendance on the great, and has entrance to the ruler.

5.verse: He travels among the peoples of foreign lands to learn what is good and evil among men.

6.verse: His care is to seek the LORD, his Maker, to petition the Most High, To open his lips in prayer, to ask pardon for his sins. Then, if it pleases the LORD Almighty, he will be filled with the spirit of understanding; He will pour forth his words of wisdom and in prayer give thanks to the LORD,

7.verse: Who will direct his knowledge and his counsel, as he meditates upon his mysteries.

8.verse: He will show the wisdom of what he has learned and glory in the law of the LORD'S covenant.

9.verse: Many will praise his understanding; his fame can never be effaced; Unfading will be his memory, through all generations his name will live;

10.verse: Peoples will speak of his wisdom, and in assembly sing his praises.

11.verse: While he lives he is one out of a thousand, and when he dies his renown will not cease.

12.verse: Once more I will set forth my theme to shine like the moon in its fullness!

13.verse: Listen, my faithful children: open up your petals, like roses planted near running waters;

14.verse: Send up the sweet odor of incense, break forth in blossoms like the lily. Send up the sweet odor of your hymn of praise; bless the LORD for all he has done!

15.verse: Proclaim the greatness of his name, loudly sing his praises, With music on the harp and all stringed instruments; sing out with joy as you proclaim:

16.verse: The works of God are all of them good; in its own time every need is supplied.

17.verse: At his word the waters become still as in a flask; he had but to speak and the reservoirs were made.

18.verse: He has but to command and his will is done; nothing can limit his achievement.

19.verse: The works of all mankind are present to him; not a thing escapes his eye.

20.verse: His gaze spans all the ages; to him there is nothing unexpected.

21.verse: No cause then to say: "What is the purpose of this?" Everything is chosen to satisfy a need.

22.verse: His blessing overflows like the Nile; like the Euphrates it enriches the surface of the earth.

23.verse: Again, his wrath expels the nations and turns fertile land into a salt marsh.

24.verse: For the virtuous his paths are level, to the haughty they are steep;

25.verse: Good things for the good he provided from the beginning, but for the wicked good things and bad.

26.verse: Chief of all needs for human life are water and fire, iron and salt, The heart of the wheat, milk and honey, the blood of the grape, and oil, and cloth;

27.verse: For the good all these are good, but for the wicked they turn out evil.

28.verse: There are storm winds created to punish, which in their fury can dislodge mountains; When destruction must be, they hurl all their force and appease the anger of their Maker.

29.verse: In his treasury also, kept for the proper time, are fire and hail, famine, disease,

30.verse: Ravenous beasts, scorpions, vipers, and the avenging sword to exterminate the wicked;

31.verse: In doing his bidding they rejoice, in their assignments they disobey not his command.

32.verse: So from the first I took my stand, and wrote down as my theme:

33.verse: The works of God are all of them good; every need when it comes he fills.

34.verse: No cause then to say: "This is not as good as that"; for each shows its worth at the proper time.

35.verse: So now with full joy of heart proclaim and bless the name of the Holy One.

annotations.1: [12-35] The sage invites his disciples to join him in joyfully proclaiming his favorite theme: The works of God are all of them good; in its own time every need is supplied ( Sirach 39:12-16, 32-35). He describes God's omniscience, supreme power and wisdom, whereby all created things, good in themselves, are ever present to him, obey him, and fulfill their intended purpose ( Sirach 39:17-21), bringing blessing to the virtuous, but evil and punishment to the wicked who misuse them ( Sirach 39:22-31). Cf similar hymns of praise, Sirach 36:1-17; 42:15- 43:35.

1.verse: My son, when you come to serve the LORD, prepare yourself for trials.

2.verse: Be sincere of heart and steadfast, undisturbed in time of adversity.

3.verse: Cling to him, forsake him not; thus will your future be great.

4.verse: Accept whatever befalls you, in crushing misfortune be patient;

5.verse: For in fire gold is tested, and worthy men in the crucible of humiliation.

6.verse: Trust God and he will help you; make straight your ways and hope in him.

7.verse: You who fear the LORD, wait for his mercy, turn not away lest you fall.

8.verse: You who fear the LORD, trust him, and your reward will not be lost.

9.verse: You who fear the LORD, hope for good things, for lasting joy and mercy.

10.verse: Study the generations long past and understand; has anyone hoped in the LORD and been disappointed? Has anyone persevered in his fear and been forsaken? has anyone called upon him and been rebuffed?

11.verse: Compassionate and merciful is the LORD; he forgives sins, he saves in time of trouble.

12.verse: Woe to craven hearts and drooping hands, to the sinner who treads a double path!

13.verse: Woe to the faint of heart who trust not, who therefore will have no shelter!

14.verse: Woe to you who have lost hope! what will you do at the visitation of the LORD?

15.verse: Those who fear the LORD disobey not his words; those who love him keep his ways.

16.verse: Those who fear the LORD seek to please him, those who love him are filled with his law.

17.verse: Those who fear the LORD prepare their hearts and humble themselves before him.

18.verse: Let us fall into the hands of the LORD and not into the hands of men, For equal to his majesty is the mercy that he shows.

annotations.1: [1-11] Serving God is not without its trials ( Sirach 2:1); moreover, it must be done with sincerity, steadfastness and fidelity ( Sirach 2:2-3). Misfortune and humiliation merely purify man and prove his worth ( Sirach 2:4-5). Patience and unwavering trust in God are always rewarded with the benefits of God's mercy and of lasting joy ( Sirach 2:6-11).
annotations.2: [12-17] A warning to those who compromise their religion in time of affliction; they fail in courage and trust and therefore have no security ( Sirach 2:12-14). But those who fear the Lord through obedience, reverence, love and humility find his mercy equal to his majesty ( Sirach 2:15-17)

1.verse: Wisdom sings her own praises, before her own people she proclaims her glory;

2.verse: In the assembly of the Most High she opens her mouth, in the presence of his hosts she declares her worth:

3.verse: "From the mouth of the Most High I came forth, and mistlike covered the earth.

4.verse: In the highest heavens did I dwell, my throne on a pillar of cloud.

5.verse: The vault of heaven I compassed alone, through the deep abyss I wandered.

6.verse: Over waves of the sea, over all the land, over every people and nation I held sway.

7.verse: Among all these I sought a resting place; in whose inheritance should I abide?

8.verse: "Then the Creator of all gave me his command, and he who formed me chose the spot for my tent, Saying, 'In Jacob make your dwelling, in Israel your inheritance.'

9.verse: Before all ages, in the beginning, he created me, and through all ages I shall not cease to be.

10.verse: In the holy tent I ministered before him, and in Zion I fixed my abode.

11.verse: Thus in the chosen city he has given me rest, in Jerusalem is my domain.

12.verse: I have struck root among the glorious people, in the portion of the LORD, his heritage.

13.verse: "Like a cedar on Lebanon I am raised aloft, like a cypress on Mount Hermon,

14.verse: Like a palm tree in En-gedi, like a rosebush in Jericho, Like a fair olive tree in the field, like a plane tree growing beside the water.

15.verse: Like cinnamon, or fragrant balm, or precious myrrh, I give forth perfume; Like galbanum and onycha and sweet spices, like the odor of incense in the holy place.

16.verse: I spread out my branches like a terebinth, my branches so bright and so graceful.

17.verse: I bud forth delights like the vine, my blossoms become fruit fair and rich.

18.verse: Come to me, all you that yearn for me, and be filled with my fruits;

19.verse: You will remember me as sweeter than honey, better to have than the honeycomb.

20.verse: He who eats of me will hunger still, he who drinks of me will thirst for more;

21.verse: He who obeys me will not be put to shame, he who serves me will never fail."

22.verse: All this is true of the book of the Most High's covenant, the law which Moses commanded us as an inheritance for the community of Jacob.

23.verse: It overflows, like the Pishon, with wisdom - like the Tigris in the days of the new fruits.

24.verse: It runs over, like the Euphrates, with understanding, like the Jordan at harvest time.

25.verse: It sparkles like the Nile with knowledge, like the Gihon at vintage time.

26.verse: The first man never finished comprehending wisdom, nor will the last succeed in fathoming her.

27.verse: For deeper than the sea are her thoughts; her counsels, than the great abyss.

28.verse: Now I, like a rivulet from her stream, channeling the waters into a garden,

29.verse: Said to myself, "I will water my plants, my flower bed I will drench"; And suddenly this rivulet of mine became a river, then this stream of mine, a sea.

30.verse: Thus do I send my teachings forth shining like the dawn, to become known afar off.

31.verse: Thus do I pour out instruction like prophecy and bestow it on generations to come.

annotations.1: [1-27] In this chapter Wisdom speaks in the first person, describing her origin, her dwelling place in Israel, and the reward she gives her followers. As in Prov 8 Wisdom is described as a being who comes from God and is distinct from him. While we do not say with certainty that this description applies to a personal being, it does foreshadow the beautiful doctrine of the Word of God later developed in St. John's Gospel ( John 1:1-14). In the liturgy this chapter is applied to the Blessed Virgin because of her constant and intimate association with Christ, the Incarnate Wisdom.
annotations.2: [15] These substances were associated with worship, being mentioned in Exodus 30:22, 23, 34 as the ingredients of the anointing oil and the sacred incense. Israel was a priestly nation
annotations.3: [18] Compare the words of the Savior in Matthew 11:28-30
annotations.4: [20] So pleasing is wisdom to man that, far from being satiated, he will always desire more
annotations.5: [22] Here the author begins to speak once more, Wisdom having ended her discourse in the preceding verse. Wisdom and the law of Moses are now identified
annotations.6: [25] Gihon: understood by some to have been a name for the Nile: cf Genesis 2:13
annotations.7: [28-31] Spoken by the author. He had at first drawn a small portion of the water of wisdom for his own private benefit, but finding it so useful, he soon began to let others share in this boon by teaching them the lessons of wisdom

1.verse: Happy the man whose mouth brings him no grief, who is not stung by remorse for sin.

2.verse: Happy the man whose conscience does not reproach him, who has not lost hope.

3.verse: Wealth ill becomes the mean man; and to the miser, of what use is gold?

4.verse: What he denies himself he collects for others, and in his possessions a stranger will revel.

5.verse: To whom will he be generous who is stingy with himself and does not enjoy what is his own?

6.verse: None is more stingy than he who is stingy with himself; he punishes his own miserliness.

7.verse: If ever he is generous, it is by mistake; and in the end he displays his greed.

8.verse: In the miser's opinion his share is too small;

9.verse: he refuses his neighbor and brings ruin on himself.

10.verse: The miser's eye is rapacious for bread, but on his own table he sets it stale.

11.verse: My son, use freely whatever you have and enjoy it as best you can;

12.verse: Remember that death does not tarry, nor have you been told the grave's appointed time.

13.verse: Before you die, be good to your friend, and give him a share in what you possess.

14.verse: Deprive not yourself of present good things, let no choice portion escape you.

15.verse: Will you not leave your riches to others, and your earnings to be divided by lot?

16.verse: Give, take, and treat yourself well, for in the nether world there are no joys to seek.

17.verse: All flesh grows old, like a garment; the age-old law is: All must die.

18.verse: As with the leaves that grow on a vigorous tree: one falls off and another sprouts - So with the generations of flesh and blood: one dies and another is born.

19.verse: All man's works will perish in decay, and his handiwork will follow after him.

20.verse: Happy the man who meditates on wisdom, and reflects on knowledge;

21.verse: Who ponders her ways in his heart, and understands her paths;

22.verse: Who pursues her like a scout, and lies in wait at her entry way;

23.verse: Who peeps through her windows, and listens at her doors;

24.verse: Who encamps near her house, and fastens his tent pegs next to her walls;

25.verse: Who pitches his tent beside her, and lives as her welcome neighbor;

26.verse: Who builds his nest in her leafage, and lodges in her branches;

27.verse: Who takes shelter with her from the heat, and dwells in her home.

annotations.1: [3-16] The miser does no good even to himself ( Sirach 14:3-10); wealth should be wisely used during life, for it must be left behind at death ( Sirach 14:11-16). In the light of the gospel, generosity has a higher motivation and promise of reward than the Old Testament writer could propose. Cf Matthew 6:19-21; Luke 12:32-34.
annotations.2: [ 14:20- 15:20] From his social teaching the sage now turns to consider individual responsibility. Happiness is to be found in the pursuit and possession of wisdom ( Sirach 14:20- 15:5). Joy and honor are given, not to the sinner ( Sirach 14:7-9), but to him who fears God and observes his law ( Sirach 14:1-6, 10). The sinner is fully responsible for his conduct because God, who sees all things ( Sirach 14:18-19), is not the author of wickedness ( Sirach 15:11-13, 20): he gives to every man the liberty to choose between good and evil ( Sirach 15:14-17)

1.verse: Contend not with an influential man, lest you fall into his power.

2.verse: Quarrel not with a rich man, lest he pay out the price of your downfall; For gold has dazzled many, and perverts the character of princes.

3.verse: Dispute not with a man of railing speech, heap no wood upon his fire.

4.verse: Be not too familiar with an unruly man, lest he speak ill of your forebears.

5.verse: Shame not a repentant sinner; remember, we all are guilty.

6.verse: Insult no man when he is old, for some of us, too, will grow old.

7.verse: Rejoice not when a man dies; remember, we are all to die.

8.verse: Spurn not the discourse of the wise, but acquaint yourself with their proverbs; From them you will acquire the training to serve in the presence of princes.

9.verse: Reject not the tradition of old men which they have learned from their fathers; From it you will obtain the knowledge how to answer in time of need.

10.verse: Kindle not the coals of a sinner, lest you be consumed in his flaming fire.

11.verse: Let not the impious man intimidate you; it will set him in ambush against you.

12.verse: Lend not to one more powerful than yourself; and whatever you lend, count it as lost.

13.verse: Go not surety beyond your means; think any pledge a debt you must pay.

14.verse: Contend not at law with a judge, for he will settle it according to his whim.

15.verse: Travel not with a ruthless man, lest he weigh you down with calamity; For he will go his own way straight, and through his folly you will perish with him.

16.verse: Provoke no quarrel with a quick-tempered man, nor ride with him through the desert, For bloodshed is nothing to him; when there is no one to help you, he will destroy you.

17.verse: Take no counsel with a fool, for he can keep nothing to himself.

18.verse: Before a stranger do nothing that should be kept secret, for you know not what it will engender.

19.verse: Open your heart to no man, and banish not your happiness.

annotations.1: [1-19] A prudent man will be circumspect, avoiding conflict with the powerful, the rich and insolent, the impious, the irascible, and with judges ( Sirach 8:1-3, 10-12, 14, 16). He will seek friendship not with the undisciplined ( Sirach 8:4, 12- 13) and the ruthless ( Sirach 8:15), nor with fools and strangers ( Sirach 8:17-19), but with the wise and the ancients of the people ( Sirach 8:8, 9).
annotations.2: [5] We all are guilty: cf 1 Kings 8:46; 2 Chron 6:36; Eccl 7:20; Romans 3:9-10; 1 John 1:8
annotations.3: [11] To give in to the wicked in one instance becomes an occasion of sin for the future

1.verse: If you do good, know for whom you are doing it, and your kindness will have its effect.

2.verse: Do good to the just man and reward will be yours, if not from him, from the LORD.

3.verse: No good comes to him who gives comfort to the wicked, nor is it an act of mercy that he does.

4.verse: Give to the good man, refuse the sinner; refresh the downtrodden, give nothing to the proud man.

5.verse: No arms for combat should you give him, lest he use them against yourself;

6.verse: With twofold evil you will meet for every good deed you do for him.

7.verse: The Most High himself hates sinners, and upon the wicked he takes vengeance.

8.verse: In our prosperity we cannot know our friends; in adversity an enemy will not remain concealed.

9.verse: When a man is successful even his enemy is friendly; in adversity even his friend disappears.

10.verse: Never trust your enemy, for his wickedness is like corrosion in bronze.

11.verse: Even though he acts humbly and peaceably toward you, take care to be on your guard against him. Rub him as one polishes a brazen mirror, and you will find that there is still corrosion.

12.verse: Let him not stand near you, lest he oust you and take your place. Let him not sit at your right hand, lest he then demand your seat, And in the end you appreciate my advice, when you groan with regret, as I warned you.

13.verse: Who pities a snake charmer when he is bitten, or anyone who goes near a wild beast?

14.verse: So is it with the companion of the proud man, who is involved in his sins:

15.verse: While you stand firm, he makes no bold move; but if you slip, he cannot hold back.

16.verse: With his lips an enemy speaks sweetly, but in his heart he schemes to plunge you into the abyss. Though your enemy has tears in his eyes, if given the chance, he will never have enough of your blood.

17.verse: If evil comes upon you, you will find him at hand; feigning to help, he will trip you up,

18.verse: Then he will nod his head and clap his hands and hiss repeatedly, and show his true face.

annotations.1: [1-7] The limitations to the practice of charity here reflected were removed by Christ, who requires that good be done even to enemies and to those who hate, persecute and calumniate us ( Matthew 5:43-48).
annotations.2: [3-5] The author advises against generosity to those who would abuse it
annotations.3: [8-18] Through adversity friends are distinguished from enemies; to trust the latter or permit them intimacy is to invite disaster. Cf note on Sirach 6:5-17
annotations.4: [11] Brazen mirror: see note on Exodus 38:8

1.verse: Rely not on your wealth; say not: "I have the power."

2.verse: Rely not on your strength in following the desires of your heart.

3.verse: Say not: "Who can prevail against me?" for the LORD will exact the punishment.

4.verse: Say not: "I have sinned, yet what has befallen me?" for the LORD bides his time.

5.verse: Of forgiveness be not overconfident, adding sin upon sin.

6.verse: Say not: "Great is his mercy; my many sins he will forgive."

7.verse: For mercy and anger alike are with him; upon the wicked alights his wrath.

8.verse: Delay not your conversion to the LORD, put it not off from day to day;

9.verse: For suddenly his wrath flames forth; at the time of vengeance, you will be destroyed.

10.verse: Rely not upon deceitful wealth, for it will be no help on the day of wrath.

11.verse: Winnow not in every wind, and start not off in every direction.

12.verse: Be consistent in your thoughts; steadfast be your words.

13.verse: Be swift to hear, but slow to answer.

14.verse: If you have the knowledge, answer your neighbor; if not, put your hand over your mouth.

15.verse: Honor and dishonor through talking! A man's tongue can be his downfall.

16.verse: Be not called a detractor; use not your tongue for calumny;

17.verse: For shame has been created for the thief, and the reproach of his neighbor for the double-tongued.

annotations.1: [1-10] The vices of the rich are pride and independence ( Sirach 5:1-2), presumption ( Sirach 5:3), false security ( Sirach 5:4-7), and impenitence ( Sirach 5:8), which cannot escape the divine wrath ( Sirach 5:9, 10). Cf Proverb 18:23; 19:1; 28:6.
annotations.2: [11] A proverbial expression condemning inconstancy and advocating sincerity and honesty
annotations.3: [ 5:12- 6:1] Proper use of the tongue requires constancy in speech ( Sirach 5:12), prudence ( Sirach 5:13-14), reserve ( Sirach 5:15), charity ( Sirach 6:1), as well as the avoidance of detraction, calumny ( Sirach 6:16), and double talk, which bring shame and disgrace ( Sirach 5:15; 6:1)

1.verse: Till like a fire there appeared the prophet whose words were as a flaming furnace.

2.verse: Their staff of bread he shattered, in his zeal he reduced them to straits;

3.verse: By God's word he shut up the heavens and three times brought down fire.

4.verse: How awesome are you, ELIJAH! Whose glory is equal to yours?

5.verse: You brought a dead man back to life from the nether world, by the will of the LORD.

6.verse: You sent kings down to destruction, and nobles, from their beds of sickness.

7.verse: You heard threats at Sinai, at Horeb avenging judgments.

8.verse: You anointed kings who should inflict vengeance, and a prophet as your successor.

9.verse: You were taken aloft in a whirlwind, in a chariot with fiery horses.

10.verse: You are destined, it is written, in time to come to put an end to wrath before the day of the LORD, To turn back the hearts of fathers toward their sons, and to reestablish the tribes of Jacob.

11.verse: Blessed is he who shall have seen you before he dies,

12.verse: O Elijah, enveloped in the whirlwind! Then ELISHA, filled with a twofold portion of his spirit, wrought many marvels by his mere word. During his lifetime he feared no one, nor was any man able to intimidate his will.

13.verse: Nothing was beyond his power; beneath him flesh was brought back into life.

14.verse: In life he performed wonders, and after death, marvelous deeds.

15.verse: Despite all this the people did not repent, nor did they give up their sins, Until they were rooted out of their land and scattered all over the earth. But Judah remained, a tiny people, with its rulers from the house of David.

16.verse: Some of these did what was right, but others were extremely sinful.

17.verse: HEZEKIAH fortified his city and had water brought into it; With iron tools he cut through the rock and he built reservoirs for water.

18.verse: During his reign Sennacherib led an invasion and sent his adjutant; He shook his fist at Zion and blasphemed God in his pride.

19.verse: The people's hearts melted within them, and they were in anguish like that of childbirth.

20.verse: But they called upon the Most High God and lifted up their hands to him; He heard the prayer they uttered, and saved them through ISAIAH.

21.verse: God struck the camp of the Assyrians and routed them with a plague.

22.verse: For Hezekiah did what was right and held fast to the paths of David, As ordered by the illustrious prophet Isaiah, who saw the truth in visions.

23.verse: In his lifetime he turned back the sun and prolonged the life of the king.

24.verse: By his powerful spirit he looked into the future and consoled the mourners of Zion;

25.verse: He foretold what should be till the end of time, hidden things yet to be fulfilled.

annotations.1: [12-16] Elisha fearlessly continued the work of his predecessor by numerous miracles ( Sirach 48:12-14), but the obstinacy of the people eventually brought on the destruction of the kingdom of Israel and the dispersion of its subjects. Judah, however, survived under the rule of Davidic kings, both good and bad ( Sirach 48:15-16).
annotations.2: [17-25] The fidelity, trust and courage of King Hezekiah ( Sirach 48:17, 22), the zeal of the prophet Isaiah, and the prayer of the people ( Sirach 48:20) availed with God. The Assyrian oppressors were routed ( Sirach 48:18-19, 21), the king's life was prolonged, and consolations were granted the people through Isaiah's prophecies concerning the future ( Sirach 48:23-25), especially the coming of the Messiah and the establishment of his kingdom; cf Isaiah 7:14; 9:6-7; 40-65

1.verse: The sluggard is like a stone in the mud; everyone hisses at his disgrace.

2.verse: The sluggard is like a lump of dung; whoever touches him wipes his hands.

3.verse: An unruly child is a disgrace to its father; if it be a daughter she brings him to poverty.

4.verse: A thoughtful daughter becomes a treasure to her husband, a shameless one is her father's grief.

5.verse: A hussy shames her father and her husband; by both she is despised.

6.verse: Like a song in time of mourning is inopportune talk, but lashes and discipline are at all times wisdom.

7.verse: Teaching a fool is like gluing a broken pot, or like disturbing a man in the depths of sleep;

8.verse: He talks with a slumberer who talks with a fool, for when it is over, he will say, "What was that?"

9.verse: Weep over the dead man, for his light has gone out; weep over the fool, for sense has left him.

10.verse: Weep but a little over the dead man, for he is at rest; but worse than death is the life of a fool.

11.verse: Seven days of mourning for the dead, but for the wicked fool a whole lifetime.

12.verse: Speak but seldom with the stupid man, be not the companion of a brute;

13.verse: Beware of him lest you have trouble and be spattered when he shakes himself; Turn away from him and you will find rest and not be wearied by his lack of sense.

14.verse: What is heavier than lead, and what is its name but "Fool"?

15.verse: Sand and salt and an iron mass are easier to bear than a stupid man.

16.verse: Masonry bonded with wooden beams is not loosened by an earthquake; Neither is a resolve constructed with careful deliberation shaken in a moment of fear.

17.verse: A resolve that is backed by prudent understanding is like the polished surface of a smooth wall.

18.verse: Small stones lying on an open height will not remain when the wind blows; Neither can a timid resolve based on foolish plans withstand fear of any kind.

19.verse: One who jabs the eye brings tears: he who pierces the heart bares its feelings.

20.verse: He who throws stones at birds drives them away, and he who insults a friend breaks up the friendship.

21.verse: Should you draw a sword against a friend, despair not, it can be undone.

22.verse: Should you speak sharply to a friend, fear not, you can be reconciled. But a contemptuous insult, a confidence broken, or a treacherous attack will drive away any friend.

23.verse: Make fast friends with a man while he is poor; thus will you enjoy his prosperity with him. In time of trouble remain true to him, so as to share in his inheritance when it comes.

24.verse: Before flames burst forth an oven smokes; so does abuse come before bloodshed.

25.verse: From a friend in need of support no one need hide in shame;

26.verse: But from him who brings harm to his friend all will stand aloof who hear of it.

27.verse: Who will set a guard over my mouth, and upon my lips an effective seal, That I may not fail through them, that my tongue may not destroy me?

annotations.1: [1-15] To Sirach, a lazy person and an unruly child are a cause of shame and disgrace; everyone wishes to be rid of them ( Sirach 22:1-5). A wicked fool is as senseless as a man asleep or dead, but the grief he causes others lasts a lifetime ( Sirach 22:7-11). He is like a brute, troublesome and intolerable ( Sirach 22:12-15).
annotations.2: [6] Like a song . . . is . . . talk: some understand talk in the sense of a rebuke unheeded by the unruly as a joyful song is out of place among mourners. Corporal punishment, however, is always effective
annotations.3: [16-18] A prudent mind firmly resolved is undisturbed by violent and conflicting thoughts, whereas a foolish person is tossed about by the winds of fear, like small stones whipped about by high winds
annotations.4: [19-26] As disputes and violence weaken friendship, and disloyalty and abuse of confidence destroy it utterly ( Sirach 22:19-22, 24, 26), so kindness to a poor man in time of poverty and adversity builds up friendship and merits a share in his prosperity and inheritance ( Sirach 22:23, 25)
annotations.5: [ 22:27- 23:6] The sage implores the divine assistance to preserve him through stern discipline from sins of the tongue ( Sirach 22:27; 23:1); ignorance of mind and weakness of will ( Sirach 22:2, 3); and inclinations of the senses and the flesh, lest he fall into the hands of his enemies, or become a prey of shameful desires ( Sirach 23:3-6)

1.verse: No evil can harm the man who fears the LORD; through trials, again and again he is safe.

2.verse: He who hates the law is without wisdom, and is tossed about like a boat in a storm.

3.verse: The prudent man trusts in the word of the LORD, and the law is dependable for him as a divine oracle.

4.verse: Prepare your words and you will be listened to; draw upon your training, and then give your answer.

5.verse: Like the wheel of a cart is the mind of a fool; his thoughts revolve in circles.

6.verse: A fickle friend is like the stallion that neighs, no matter who the rider.

7.verse: Why is one day more important than another, when it is the sun that lights up every day?

8.verse: It is due to the LORD'S wisdom that they differ; it is through him the seasons and feasts come and go.

9.verse: Some he dignifies and sanctifies, and others he lists as ordinary days.

10.verse: So too, all men are of clay, for from earth man was formed;

11.verse: Yet with his great knowledge the LORD makes men unlike; in different paths he has them walk.

12.verse: Some he blesses and makes great, some he sanctifies and draws to himself. Others he curses and brings low, and expels them from their place.

13.verse: Like clay in the hands of a potter, to be molded according to his pleasure, So are men in the hands of their Creator, to be assigned by him their function.

14.verse: As evil contrasts with good, and death with life, so are sinners in contrast with the just;

15.verse: See now all the works of the Most High: they come in pairs, the one the opposite of the other.

16.verse: Now I am the last to keep vigil, like a gleaner after the vintage;

17.verse: Since by the LORD'S blessing I have made progress till like a vintager I have filled my wine press,

18.verse: I would inform you that not for myself only have I toiled, but for every seeker after wisdom.

19.verse: Listen to me, O leaders of the multitude; O rulers of the assembly, give ear!

20.verse: Let neither son nor wife, neither brother nor friend, have power over you as long as you live.

21.verse: While breath of life is still in you, let no man have dominion over you. Give not to another your wealth, lest then you have to plead with him;

22.verse: Far better that your children plead with you than that you should look to their generosity.

23.verse: Keep control over all your affairs; let no one tarnish your glory.

24.verse: When your few days reach their limit, at the time of death distribute your inheritance.

25.verse: Fodder and whip and loads for an ass; the yoke and harness and the rod of his master.

27.verse: Food, correction and work for a slave; and for a wicked slave, punishment in the stocks.

26.verse: Make a slave work and he will look for his rest; let his hands be idle and he will seek to be free.

28.verse: Force him to work that he be not idle, for idleness is an apt teacher of mischief.

29.verse: Put him to work, for that is what befits him; if he becomes unruly, load him with chains.

30.verse: But never lord it over any human being, and do nothing unjust.

31.verse: If you have but one slave, treat him like yourself, for you have acquired him with your life's blood;

32.verse: If you have but one slave, deal with him as a brother, for you need him as you need your life:

33.verse: If you mistreat him and he runs away, in what direction will you look for him?

annotations.1: [3] Oracle: as the answer given through the Urim and Thummim to the high priest is true, so the law proves itself true to him who obeys it. Cf Exodus 28:30; Numbers 27:21.
annotations.2: [5-15] Contrasts observable in the physical universe as well as in the moral order serve the purposes of divine wisdom ( Sirach 33:5-9). All creatures are like clay. . . in the hands of their Creator - the fool and the wise man, the sinner, and the just ( Sirach 33:10-15). This does not imply that man is created to be a sinner: God is not the author of wickedness. Cf James 1:13-14
annotations.3: [16-18] Here the author refers to himself as the most recent of the writers who have endeavored to present true wisdom to their readers
annotations.4: [19-33] Public officials should reject every influence that would restrict their freedom in the management of their affairs. They must make their own household subservient to them rather than be subservient to it ( Sirach 33:19-24). Slaves are to be given food and work and correction but never to be treated unjustly ( Sirach 33:25-29). Great care should be taken of good slaves ( Sirach 33:30-33)

1.verse: If you are chosen to preside at dinner, be not puffed up, but with the guests be as one of themselves; Take care of them first before you sit down;

2.verse: when you have fulfilled your duty, then take your place, To share in their joy and win praise for your hospitality.

3.verse: Being older, you may talk; that is only your right, but temper your wisdom, not to disturb the singing.

4.verse: When wine is present, do not pour out discourse, and flaunt not your wisdom at the wrong time.

5.verse: Like a seal of carnelian in a setting of gold is a concert when wine is served.

6.verse: Like a gold mounting with an emerald seal is string music with delicious wine.

7.verse: Young man, speak only when necessary, when they have asked you more than once;

8.verse: Be brief, but say much in those few words, be like the wise man, taciturn.

9.verse: When among your elders be not forward, and with officials be not too insistent.

10.verse: Like the lightning that flashes before a storm is the esteem that shines on modesty.

11.verse: When it is time to leave, tarry not; be off for home! There take your ease,

12.verse: And there enjoy doing as you wish, but without sin or words of pride.

13.verse: Above all, give praise to your Creator, who showers his favors upon you.

14.verse: He who would find God must accept discipline; he who seeks him obtains his request.

15.verse: He who studies the law masters it, but the hypocrite finds it a trap.

16.verse: His judgment is sound who fears the LORD; out of obscurity he draws forth a clear plan.

17.verse: The sinner turns aside reproof and distorts the law to suit his purpose.

18.verse: The thoughtful man will not neglect direction; the proud and insolent man is deterred by nothing.

19.verse: Do nothing without counsel, and then you need have no regrets.

20.verse: Go not on a way that is set with snares, and let not the same thing trip you twice.

21.verse: Be not too sure even of smooth roads,

22.verse: be careful on all your paths.

23.verse: Whatever you do, be on your guard, for in this way you will keep the commandments.

24.verse: He who keeps the law preserves himself; and he who trusts in the LORD shall not be put to shame.

annotations.1: [ 32:14- 33:4] God is shown to reveal himself through the discipline of his law, a clear and safe plan of life for the pious Jew of old. Direction and counsel are aids in following it ( Sirach 32:14-16, 18-24; 33:1, 3, 4). Sinners and hypocrites, hating the law or distorting it, fail in wisdom and are devoid of security ( Sirach 32:15, 17-18; 33:2).

1.verse: The greatest among his brethren, the glory of his people, was SIMON the priest, son of Jochanan, In whose time the house of God was renovated, in whose days the temple was reinforced.

2.verse: In his time also the wall was built with powerful turrets for the temple precincts;

3.verse: In his time the reservoir was dug, the pool with a vastness like the sea's.

4.verse: He protected his people against brigands and strengthened his city against the enemy.

5.verse: How splendid he was as he appeared from the tent, as he came from within the veil!

6.verse: Like a star shining among the clouds, like the full moon at the holyday season;

7.verse: Like the sun shining upon the temple, like the rainbow appearing in the cloudy sky;

8.verse: Like the blossoms on the branches in springtime, like a lily on the banks of a stream; Like the trees of Lebanon in summer,

9.verse: like the fire of incense at the sacrifice; Like a vessel of beaten gold, studded with precious stones;

10.verse: Like a luxuriant olive tree thick with fruit, like a cypress standing against the clouds;

11.verse: Vested in his magnificent robes, and wearing his garments of splendor, As he ascended the glorious altar and lent majesty to the court of the sanctuary.

12.verse: When he received the sundered victims from the priests while he stood before the sacrificial wood, His brethren ringed him about like a garland, like a stand of cedars on Lebanon;

13.verse: All the sons of Aaron in their dignity clustered around him like poplars, With the offerings to the LORD in their hands, in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel.

14.verse: Once he had completed the services at the altar with the arranging of the sacrifices for the Most High,

15.verse: And had stretched forth his hand for the cup, to offer blood of the grape, And poured it out at the foot of the altar, a sweet-smelling odor to the Most High God,

16.verse: The sons of Aaron would sound a blast, the priests, on their trumpets of beaten metal; A blast to resound mightily as a reminder before the Most High.

annotations.1: [1-21] The son of Jochanan here mentioned was Simon II, in whose time as high priest (219-196 B.C.) great works were accomplished for the benefit of public worship and welfare ( Sirach 50:1-4). The author, a contemporary of this high priest, describes in great detail and by numerous comparisons the impression of awful majesty received, the lofty joy aroused, at sight of the high priest fully vested entering the sanctuary, ascending the altar ( Sirach 50:6-11), and, in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel, encircled by assistant priests bearing offerings, sacrificing the burnt offering on the Day of Atonement, while the trumpets blast and the people bow down in adoration of the Most High ( Sirach 50:12-17). The hymnody, the joyful shouts of the multitude, and finally the high priest's blessing, in which he pronounces-once only in the year, on this occasion - the holy name of Yahweh, climax the description of this most solemn Jewish liturgical function ( Sirach 50:18-21).
annotations.2: [22-24] Praise and thanksgiving are given to God for his wondrous works, and a blessing is invoked on man that he may enjoy peace and gladness of heart and the abiding goodness of the Most High
annotations.3: [25-26] The author's abhorrence of the pagan Edomites (Idumeans), Philistines and Samaritans can be understood in the light of Old Testament thinking, which does not always distinguish between hatred of evildoers and hatred of the evil they do
annotations.4: [25] Not even a people: the Samaritans
annotations.5: [26] Seir: Mount Seir in the territory of the Edomites. Shechem: a city in Samaria
annotations.6: [27-29] These verses contain the subscription of the author, Jesus, son of Eleazar, son of Sirach, to his long and beautiful treatise on wisdom as applying to all of human life, integrating it under the direction of the fear of the Lord

False friendship based on hypocrisy and deceit is hateful to God and man ( Sirach 27:22-24); it soon becomes a victim of its own treachery ( Sirach 27:25-27). The same fate awaits the malicious and vengeful ( Sirach 27:28- 28:1). They can obtain mercy and forgiveness only by first forgiving their neighbor, being mindful of death and of the commandments of the Most High ( Sirach 28:2-7). annotations.1: [ 44:1- 50:24] As in the previous section God's wisdom shone forth in the works of nature, so in these chapters it is also revealed through the history of God's people as seen in the lives of their patriarchs, prophets, priests and rulers. verses.1:
Foreword
Many important truths have been handed down to us through the law, the prophets, and the later authors; and for these the instruction and wisdom of Israel merit praise. Now, those who are familiar with these truths must not only understand them themselves but, as lovers of wisdom, be able, in speech and in writing, to help others less familiar. Such a one was my grandfather, Jesus, who, having devoted himself for a long time to the diligent study of the law, the prophets, and the rest of the books1 of our ancestors, and having developed a thorough familiarity with them, was moved to write something himself in the nature of instruction and wisdom, in order that those who love wisdom might, by acquainting themselves with what he too had written, make even greater progress in living in conformity with the divine law.
You therefore are now invited to read it in a spirit of attentive good will, with indulgence for any apparent failure on our part, despite earnest efforts, in the interpretation of particular passages. For words spoken originally in Hebrew are not as effective when they are translated into another language. That is true not only of this book but of the law itself, the prophets and the rest of the books, which differ no little when they are read in the original
I arrived in Egypt in the thirty-eighth year of the reign of King Euergetes, 2 and while there, I found a reproduction of our valuable teaching. 3 I therefore considered myself in duty bound to devote some diligence and industry to the translation of this book. Many sleepless hours of close application have I devoted in the interval to finishing the book for publication, for the benefit of those living abroad who wish to acquire wisdom and are disposed to live their lives according to the standards of the law

annotations.1: [1-11] While praising brotherly love, love of neighbor, and conjugal love, the sage condemns their opposites in the arrogant pauper who despises his brother, the fraudulent rich man who cheats his neighbor, and the lecherous old man unfaithful to his wife ( Sirach 25:1, 2). annotations.2: [8] Like a donkey yoked with an ox: incompatibility between husband and wife
annotations.3: [12-25] Wickedness in a woman is most grievous, painful and bitter to her husband. Through it she becomes vengeful, dangerous and intolerable, jealous, talkative, intemperate and unchaste. Even her very appearance is changed ( Sirach 25:12-17). The worst of all evils, a source of grief, a snare and a disgrace to her husband, she depresses his mind, saddens and breaks his heart, destroys his strength ( Sirach 25:18-22). She must not be indulged but made obedient or punished ( Sirach 25:24, 25)
annotations.4: [23] According to the account in Genesis 3 to which Ben Sirach refers, sin, the cause of death, originated in woman: Eve, the first human being to sin, induced Adam to follow her example. But it is through Adam, as head of the race, that original sin and its punishment of spiritual death are presented by St. Paul (Romans 5) as having entered the world, to become the occasion for the redemptive work of Christ our Lord

annotations.1: [1-5] Moses manifested God's power through miracles ( Sirach 45:1-3), God's authority through the promulgation of the commandments and the law ( Sirach 45:5), and God's mercy through the intimacy granted him by the Lord for his own faithfulness and meekness ( Sirach 45:4-5). The very personification of the old covenant, Moses was also a type of Christ, the Prophet and Legislator of the new; cf Deut 18:15.
annotations.2: [2] God's honor devolved upon him: Moses was actually God's substitute in dealing with Pharaoh, hence God entrusted his own honor to Moses
annotations.3: [5] Face to face: on God's intimacy with Moses, see Exodus 33:11; Numbers 12:8. St. Paul alluded to this in 1 Cor 13:12
annotations.4: [6-21] The author here expresses his reverence and esteem for the priesthood of the old covenant. He recalls God's choice of Aaron and his sons for this sublime office ( Sirach 45:6, 7), and describes in detail the beauty of the high priest's vestments ( Sirach 45:8-13). He relates the ordination of Aaron at the hands of Moses, his brother ( Sirach 45:15), and describes the priestly functions, of offering sacrifice to God ( Sirach 45:16), and of blessing ( Sirach 45:15), teaching, governing and judging the people ( Sirach 45:17); the inheritance of the high priest ( Sirach 45:20-22); the punishment of those families who were jealous of Aaron ( Sirach 45:18, 19); and the confirmation of the covenant of the priesthood with Aaron's descendants through Phinehas ( Sirach 45:23-25)
annotations.5: [7] The priesthood of Aaron was superseded by the priesthood of Christ; cf Hebrews 7:18-28

11.verse: Man's body is a fleeting thing, but a virtuous name will never be annihilated.

12.verse: Have a care for your name, for it will stand by you better than precious treasures in the thousands;

13.verse: The boon of life is for limited days, but a good name, for days without number.

14.verse: My children, heed my instruction about shame; judge of disgrace only according to my rules, For it is not always well to be ashamed, nor is it always the proper thing to blush:

15.verse: Before father and mother be ashamed of immorality, before master and mistress, of falsehood;

16.verse: Before prince and ruler, of flattery; before the public assembly, of crime;

17.verse: Before friend and companion, of disloyalty, and of breaking an oath or agreement.

18.verse: Be ashamed of theft from the people where you settle, and of stretching out your elbow when you dine;

19.verse: Of refusing to give when asked, of defrauding another of his appointed share,

20.verse: Of failing to return a greeting, and of rebuffing a friend;

21.verse: Of gazing at a married woman, and of entertaining thoughts about another's wife; Of trifling with a servant girl you have, and of violating her couch;

22.verse: Of using harsh words with friends, and of following up your gifts with insults;

23.verse: Of repeating what you hear, and of betraying secrets -

24.verse: These are the things you should rightly avoid as shameful if you would be looked upon by everyone with favor.

annotations.1: [1-13] Whether death seems bitter to one who enjoys peace, success and pleasure, or welcome to one who is weak and in despair, it comes to all and must be accepted as the will of God ( Sirach 41:1-4). As the human body passes away ( Sirach 41:11), so do those who have sinned through the body and their offspring alike, who, needy and accursed, pass on with their parents as if they had never been ( Sirach 41:5-10). Only the good name of the virtuous endures ( Sirach 41:11-13).
annotations.2: [13] After this verse many texts repeat Sirach 20:29-30
annotations.3: [ 41:14- 42:8] The author illustrates the subject of true and false shame with numerous and detailed examples of sin ( Sirach 41:14-22) and virtue ( Sirach 42:1-8), following the norm of the commandments

1.verse: Keeping watch over riches wastes the flesh, and the care of wealth drives away rest.

2.verse: Concern for one's livelihood banishes slumber; more than a serious illness it disturbs repose.

3.verse: The rich man labors to pile up wealth, and his only rest is wanton pleasure;

4.verse: The poor man toils for a meager subsistence, and if ever he rests, he finds himself in want.

5.verse: The lover of gold will not be free from sin, for he who pursues wealth is led astray by it.

6.verse: Many have been ensnared by gold, though destruction lay before their eyes;

7.verse: It is a stumbling block to those who are avid for it, a snare for every fool.

8.verse: Happy the rich man found without fault, who turns not aside after gain!

9.verse: Who is he, that we may praise him? he, of all his kindred, has done wonders,

10.verse: For he has been tested by gold and come off safe, and this remains his glory; He could have sinned but did not, could have done evil but would not,

11.verse: So that his possessions are secure, and the assembly recounts his praises.

12.verse: If you are dining with a great man, bring not a greedy gullet to his table, Nor cry out, "How much food there is here!"

13.verse: Remember that gluttony is evil. No creature is greedier than the eye: therefore it weeps for any cause.

15.verse: Recognize that your neighbor feels as you do, and keep in mind your own dislikes:

14.verse: Toward what he eyes, do not put out a hand; nor reach when he does for the same dish.

16.verse: Behave at table like a favored guest, and be not greedy, lest you be despised.

17.verse: Be the first to stop, as befits good manners; gorge not yourself, lest you give offense.

18.verse: If there are many with you at table, be not the first to reach out your hand.

19.verse: Does not a little suffice for a well-bred man? When he lies down, it is without discomfort.

20.verse: Distress and anguish and loss of sleep, and restless tossing for the glutton! Moderate eating ensures sound slumber and a clear mind next day on rising.

21.verse: If perforce you have eaten too much, once you have emptied your stomach, you will have relief.

22.verse: Listen to me, my son, and scorn me not; later you will find my advice good. In whatever you do, be moderate, and no sickness will befall you.

23.verse: On a man generous with food, blessings are invoked, and this testimony to his goodness is lasting;

24.verse: He who is miserly with food is denounced in public, and this testimony to his stinginess is lasting.

25.verse: Let not wine-drinking be the proof of your strength, for wine has been the ruin of many.

26.verse: As the furnace probes the work of the smith, so does wine the hearts of the insolent.

27.verse: Wine is very life to man if taken in moderation. Does he really live who lacks the wine which was created for his joy?

28.verse: Joy of heart, good cheer and merriment are wine drunk freely at the proper time.

29.verse: Headache, bitterness and disgrace is wine drunk amid anger and strife.

30.verse: More and more wine is a snare for the fool; it lessens his strength and multiplies his wounds.

31.verse: Rebuke not your neighbor when wine is served, nor put him to shame while he is merry; Use no harsh words with him and distress him not in the presence of others.

annotations.1: [1-11] Solicitude for acquiring wealth and anxiety over preserving it disturb repose and easily lead to sin and ruin ( Sirach 31:1-7). Cf Matthew 6:25-34. A rich man who has not sinned or been seduced by wealth is worthy of praise ( Sirach 31:8-11).
annotations.2: [2] The Hebrew adds a verse that seems out of place here: "A faithful comrade drives away reproach, and the friend who keeps secrets is as dear as life."
annotations.3: [8-10] The Church in her liturgy applies this passage to holy confessors of the Faith
annotations.4: [ 31:12- 32:13] A man observing etiquette at table avoids greed and selfishness ( Sirach 31:12-13), is considerate of a neighbor's likes and dislikes and is generous toward him ( Sirach 31:14, 15, 23, 24), observes proper manners ( Sirach 31:16-18), is moderate in eating and drinking ( Sirach 31:19-22, 25-30). A good host makes himself one with his guests, is solicitous for them ( Sirach 32:1, 2), provides conversation and diversion ( Sirach 32:3-6), is modest in speech ( Sirach 32:7, 8, 10), is respectful of elders ( Sirach 32:9), polite in comportment and grateful to God for his favors ( Sirach 32:11-13)
annotations.5: [21] Emptied your stomach: the practice of induced vomiting, well-known among pagan Romans, and less well-known among the Jews, seems to be referred to here

1.verse: Be not jealous of the wife of your bosom, lest you teach her to do evil against you.

2.verse: Give no woman power over you to trample upon your dignity.

3.verse: Be not intimate with a strange woman, lest you fall into her snares.

4.verse: With a singing girl be not familiar, lest you be caught in her wiles.

5.verse: Entertain no thoughts against a virgin, lest you be enmeshed in damages for her.

6.verse: Give not yourself to harlots, lest you surrender your inheritance.

7.verse: Gaze not about the lanes of the city and wander not through its squares;

8.verse: Avert your eyes from a comely woman; gaze not upon the beauty of another's wife - Through woman's beauty many perish, for lust for it burns like fire.

9.verse: With a married woman dine not, recline not at table to drink by her side, Lest your heart be drawn to her and you go down in blood to the grave.

10.verse: Discard not an old friend, for the new one cannot equal him. A new friend is like new wine which you drink with pleasure only when it has aged.

11.verse: Envy not a sinner's fame, for you know not what disaster awaits him.

12.verse: Rejoice not at a proud man's success; remember he will not reach death unpunished.

13.verse: Keep far from the man who has power to kill, and you will not be filled with the dread of death. But if you approach him, offend him not, lest he take away your life; Know that you are stepping among snares and walking over a net.

14.verse: As best you can, take your neighbors' measure, and associate with the wise.

15.verse: With the learned be intimate; let all your conversation be about the law of the LORD.

16.verse: Have just men for your table companions; in the fear of God be your glory.

17.verse: Skilled artisans are esteemed for their deftness; but the ruler of his people is the skilled sage.

18.verse: Feared in the city is the man of railing speech, and he who talks rashly is hated.

annotations.1: [1-9] Prudence and reserve in dealing with women are the best defense of morality. To preserve the liberty and dignity of his person and the integrity of his possessions, a man must avoid jealousy toward his own wife and familiarity toward all other women. Cf Sirach 25:12- 26:18
annotations.2: [1] Unjust suspicions often engender hatred between husband and wife and may prompt a wife to commit those faults of which heretofore she had been innocent.
annotations.4: [10-16:] In social relations, adherence to the law of the Lord should serve as a guide ( Sirach 9:15). Associate with true friends ( Sirach 9:10), with the just and the learned ( Sirach 9:14-16); avoid the company of the mighty and of sinners doomed to punishment ( Sirach 9:11-13). Cf Sirach 8:1-19
annotations.5: [ 9:17- 10:5] Public office as conducted justly or unjustly benefits or destroys the people, according to the axiom, "as the prince, so the people." Cf Isaiah 24:2. God, however, has sovereignty over both

1.verse: Say nothing harmful, small or great; be not a foe instead of a friend; A bad name and disgrace will you acquire: "That for the evil man with double tongue!"

2.verse: Fall not into the grip of desire, lest, like fire, it consume your strength;

3.verse: Your leaves it will eat, your fruits destroy, and you will be left a dry tree,

4.verse: For contumacious desire destroys its owner and makes him the sport of his enemies.

5.verse: A kind mouth multiplies friends, and gracious lips prompt friendly greetings.

6.verse: Let your acquaintances be many, but one in a thousand your confidant.

7.verse: When you gain a friend, first test him, and be not too ready to trust him

8.verse: For one sort of friend is a friend when it suits him, but he will not be with you in time of distress.

9.verse: Another is a friend who becomes an enemy, and tells of the quarrel to your shame.

10.verse: Another is a friend, a boon companion, who will not be with you when sorrow comes.

11.verse: When things go well, he is your other self, and lords it over your servants;

12.verse: But if you are brought low, he turns against you and avoids meeting you.

13.verse: Keep away from your enemies; be on your guard with your friends.

14.verse: A faithful friend is a sturdy shelter; he who finds one finds a treasure.

15.verse: A faithful friend is beyond price, no sum can balance his worth.

16.verse: A faithful friend is a life-saving remedy, such as he who fears God finds;

17.verse: For he who fears God behaves accordingly, and his friend will be like himself.

18.verse: My son, from your youth embrace discipline; thus will you find wisdom with graying hair.

19.verse: As though plowing and sowing, draw close to her; then await her bountiful crops.

20.verse: For in cultivating her you will labor but little, and soon you will eat of her fruits.

21.verse: How irksome she is to the unruly! The fool cannot abide her.

22.verse: She will be like a burdensome stone to test him, and he will not delay in casting her aside.

23.verse: For discipline is like her name, she is not accessible to many.
