24.verse: Listen, my son, and heed my advice; refuse not my counsel.

25.verse: Put your feet into her fetters, and your neck under her yoke.

26.verse: Stoop your shoulders and carry her and be not irked at her bonds.

27.verse: With all your soul draw close to her; with all your strength keep her ways.

28.verse: Search her out, discover her; seek her and you will find her. Then when you have her, do not let her go;

29.verse: Thus will you afterward find rest in her, and she will become your joy.

30.verse: Her fetters will be your throne of majesty; her bonds, your purple cord.

31.verse: You will wear her as your robe of glory, bear her as your splendid crown.

32.verse: My son, if you wish, you can be taught; if you apply yourself, you will be shrewd.

33.verse: If you are willing to listen, you will learn; if you give heed, you will be wise.

34.verse: Frequent the company of the elders; whoever is wise, stay close to him.

35.verse: Be eager to hear every godly discourse; let no wise saying escape you.

36.verse: If you see a man of prudence, seek him out; let your feet wear away his doorstep!

37.verse: Reflect on the precepts of the LORD, let his commandments be your constant meditation; Then he will enlighten your mind, and the wisdom you desire he will grant.

annotations.1: [1] "That . . . double tongue!": people will say this against the man whose deceitful tongue has brought him to disgrace.
annotations.2: [5-17] True friends are discerned not by prosperity ( Sirach 6:11), but through the trials of adversity: distress, quarrels ( Sirach 6:9), sorrow ( Sirach 6:10) and misfortune ( Sirach 6:12). Such friends are rare and their value is beyond estimation, a gift from God ( Sirach 6:14-17)
annotations.3: [18-37] The various figures in each of the three strophes urge the search for wisdom through patience ( Sirach 6:19-23), docility ( Sirach 6:32-37), and perseverance in trials ( Sirach 6:25-27), promising rich rewards ( Sirach 6:28-31). Cf Sirach 4:11-19
annotations.4: [23] Discipline (musar, in the sense of wisdom) is a perfect homonym for musar, "removed, withdrawn"; thus the path of discipline is inaccessible to many
annotations.5: [31] Some forms of the text speak also of the "yoke" of wisdom under the imagery of golden ornaments

1.verse: Happy the husband of a good wife, twice-lengthened are his days;

2.verse: A worthy wife brings joy to her husband, peaceful and full is his life.

3.verse: A good wife is a generous gift bestowed upon him who fears the LORD;

4.verse: Be he rich or poor, his heart is content, and a smile is ever on his face.

5.verse: There are three things at which my heart quakes, a fourth before which I quail: Though false charges in public, trial before all the people, and lying testimony are harder to bear than death,

6.verse: A jealous wife is heartache and mourning and a scourging tongue like the other three.

7.verse: A bad wife is a chafing yoke; he who marries her seizes a scorpion.

8.verse: A drunken wife arouses great anger, for she does not hide her shame.

9.verse: By her eyelids and her haughty stare an unchaste wife can be recognized.

10.verse: Keep a strict watch over an unruly wife, lest, finding an opportunity, she make use of it;

11.verse: Follow close if her eyes are bold, and be not surprised if she betrays you:

12.verse: As a thirsty traveler with eager mouth drinks from any water that he finds, So she settles down before every tent peg and opens her quiver for every arrow.

13.verse: A gracious wife delights her husband, her thoughtfulness puts flesh on his bones;

14.verse: A gift from the LORD is her governed speech, and her firm virtue is of surpassing worth.

15.verse: Choicest of blessings is a modest wife, priceless her chaste person.

16.verse: Like the sun rising in the LORD'S heavens, the beauty of a virtuous wife is the radiance of her home.

17.verse: Like the light which shines above the holy lampstand, are her beauty of face and graceful figure.

18.verse: Golden columns on silver bases are her shapely limbs and steady feet.

19.verse: These two bring grief to my heart, and the third arouses my horror: A wealthy man reduced to want; illustrious men held in contempt; And the man who passes from justice to sin, for whom the LORD makes ready the sword.

20.verse: A merchant can hardly remain upright, nor a shopkeeper free from sin;

annotations.1: [1-4, 13-18] A good wife is as a gift from God, bringing joy and peace, happiness and contentment to her husband ( Sirach 26:1-4) through her thoughtfulness, reserve, modesty and chastity, beauty, grace and virtue ( Sirach 26:13-18).
annotations.2: [2] Worthy: gifted spiritually, mentally and physically. Cf Proverb 31:10
annotations.3: [6-12] A repetition of the thought expressed in 25:12-25
annotations.4: [17-18] The holy lampstand and the golden columns stood in the holy place of the ancient Tabernacle ( Exodus 25:31-40; 26:32)
annotations.5: [18] Among the additions found here in some manuscripts are the following lines: "My son, take care in the prime of life not to surrender your strength to strangers; Single out from the land a goodly field and there with confidence sow the seed of your increase; So shall you have your offspring around you, and in confidence shall they grow up
annotations.6: [ 26:20- 27:15] From proper conduct in family life, the author proceeds to social morality, warning especially against injustice in commerce ( Sirach 26:20- 27:3), and perversity of speech in business ( Sirach 26:4-7). The pursuit of justice in these matters is all the more meritorious as it is difficult ( Sirach 26:8-10). The discourses of the devout are marked with wisdom, but the conversations of the wicked, with offense, swearing, cursing, quarrels and even bloodshed ( Sirach 26:11-15)

1.verse: Do no evil, and evil will not overtake you;

2.verse: avoid wickedness, and it will turn aside from you.

3.verse: Sow not in the furrows of injustice, lest you harvest it sevenfold.

4.verse: Seek not from the LORD authority, nor from the king a place of honor.

5.verse: Parade not your justice before the Lord, and before the king flaunt not your wisdom.

6.verse: Seek not to become a judge if you have not strength to root out crime, Or you will show favor to the ruler and mar your integrity.

7.verse: Be guilty of no evil before the city's populace, nor disgrace yourself before the assembly.

8.verse: Do not plot to repeat a sin; not even for one will you go unpunished.

9.verse: Say not: "He will appreciate my many gifts; the Most High will accept my offerings."

10.verse: Be not impatient in prayers, and neglect not the giving of alms.

11.verse: Laugh not at an embittered man; be mindful of him who exalts and humbles.

12.verse: Plot no mischief against your brother, nor against your friend and companion.

13.verse: Delight not in telling lie after lie, for it never results in good.

14.verse: Thrust not yourself into the deliberations of princes, and repeat not the words of your prayer.

15.verse: Hate not laborious tasks, nor farming, which was ordained by the Most High.

16.verse: Do not esteem yourself better than your fellows; remember, his wrath will not delay.

17.verse: More and more, humble your pride; what awaits man is worms.

18.verse: Barter not a friend for money, nor a dear brother for the gold of Ophir.

19.verse: Dismiss not a sensible wife; a gracious wife is more precious than corals.

20.verse: Mistreat not a servant who faithfully serves, nor a laborer who devotes himself to his task.

21.verse: Let a wise servant be dear to you as your own self; refuse him not his freedom.

22.verse: If you have livestock, look after them; if they are dependable, keep them.

23.verse: If you have sons, chastise them; bend their necks from childhood.

24.verse: If you have daughters, keep them chaste, and be not indulgent to them.

25.verse: Giving your daughter in marriage ends a great task; but give her to a worthy man.

26.verse: If you have a wife, let her not seem odious to you; but where there is ill-feeling, trust her not.

27.verse: With your whole heart honor your father; your mother's birthpangs forget not.

28.verse: Remember, of these parents you were born; what can you give them for all they gave you?

29.verse: With all your soul, fear God, revere his priests.

30.verse: With all your strength, love your Creator, forsake not his ministers.

31.verse: Honor God and respect the priest; give him his portion as you have been commanded: First fruits and contributions, due sacrifices and holy offerings.

32.verse: To the poor man also extend your hand, that your blessing may be complete;

33.verse: Be generous to all the living, and withhold not your kindness from the dead.

34.verse: Avoid not those who weep, but mourn with those who mourn;

35.verse: Neglect not to visit the sick - for these things you will be loved.

36.verse: In whatever you do, remember your last days, and you will never sin.

annotations.1: [1-17] In the conduct of social relations wisdom forbids evil and injustice ( Sirach 7:1-3), pride ( Sirach 7:5, 15-17), ambition and human respect ( Sirach 7:4, 6), public disorder ( Sirach 7:7), presumption and impatience toward God ( Sirach 7:9-10), ridicule ( Sirach 7:11), mischief and deceit toward one's neighbor ( Sirach 7:8, 12-13).
annotations.2: [11] Him who exalts and humbles: God; cf 1 Sam 2:7; Psalm 75:8; Luke 1:52
annotations.3: [14] Repeat not . . . prayer: brevity of speech in dealings with superiors and more especially with God is a sign of reverence and respect; cf Eccl 5:1; Matthew 6:7
annotations.4: [18-36] The duties of respect and appreciation, justice and kindness should characterize relations toward members of the household ( Sirach 7:18-28), and also toward God and his priests ( Sirach 7:29-31), the poor and afflicted, the living and the dead ( Sirach 7:32-36)
annotations.5: [18] Ophir was the port, at present unidentified, to which the ships of Solomon sailed and from which they brought back gold and silver; cf note on Psalm 45:10
annotations.6: [21] After six years of service a Hebrew slave was entitled to freedom, cf Exodus 21:2; Deut 15:12-15
annotations.7: [23] Bend their necks: keep them from rebellious pride; so with the Greek. Cf Sirach 30:12. The present Hebrew text, which is probably not original here, reads: "Choose wives for them while they are young."
annotations.8: [31] First fruits . . . holy offerings: cf Exodus 29:27; Lev 7:31-34; Numbers 18:8-20; Deut 18:1-5
annotations.9: [33] This seems to refer to the observances ordained toward the dead, that is, proper mourning and burial. Cf 2 Sam 21:12-14; Tobit 1:20; 12:12. When this verse is read in the light of later teaching, prayers for the souls of the deceased would also be recommended. Cf 2 Macc 12:43-45

1.verse: Empty and false are the hopes of the senseless, and fools are borne aloft by dreams.

2.verse: Like a man who catches at shadows or chases the wind, is the one who believes in dreams.

3.verse: What is seen in dreams is to reality what the reflection of a face is to the face itself.

4.verse: Can the unclean produce the clean? can the liar ever speak the truth?

5.verse: Divination, omens and dreams all are unreal; what you already expect, the mind depicts.

6.verse: Unless it be a vision specially sent by the Most High, fix not your heart on it;

7.verse: For dreams have led many astray, and those who believed in them have perished.

8.verse: The law is fulfilled without fail, and perfect wisdom is found in the mouth of the faithful man.

9.verse: A man with training gains wide knowledge; a man of experience speaks sense.

10.verse: One never put to the proof knows little, whereas with travel a man adds to his resourcefulness.

11.verse: I have seen much in my travels, learned more than ever I could say.

12.verse: Often I was in danger of death, but by these attainments I was saved.

13.verse: Lively is the courage of those who fear the LORD, for they put their hope in their savior;

14.verse: He who fears the LORD is never alarmed, never afraid; for the LORD is his hope.

15.verse: Happy the soul that fears the LORD! In whom does he trust, and who is his support?

16.verse: The eyes of the LORD are upon those who love him; he is their mighty shield and strong support, A shelter from the heat, a shade from the noonday sun, a guard against stumbling, a help against falling.

17.verse: He buoys up the spirits, brings a sparkle to the eyes, gives health and life and blessing.

18.verse: Tainted his gifts who offers in sacrifice ill-gotten goods! Mock presents from the lawless win not God's favor.

19.verse: The Most High approves not the gifts of the godless, nor for their many sacrifices does he forgive their sins.

20.verse: Like the man who slays a son in his father's presence is he who offers sacrifice from the possessions of the poor.

21.verse: The bread of charity is life itself for the needy; he who withholds it is a man of blood.

22.verse: He slays his neighbor who deprives him of his living: he sheds blood who denies the laborer his wages.

23.verse: If one man builds up and another tears down, what do they gain but trouble?

24.verse: If one man prays and another curses, whose voice will the LORD hear?

25.verse: If a man again touches a corpse after he has bathed, what did he gain by the purification?

26.verse: So with a man who fasts for his sins, but then goes and commits them again: Who will hear his prayer, and what has he gained by his mortification?

annotations.1: [1-17] Confidence placed in dreams, divinations and omens is false because these are devoid of reality ( Sirach 34:1-8). True confidence is founded on knowledge and experience ( Sirach 34:9-12), and above all on the fear of the Lord, with its accompanying blessings of divine assistance and protection ( Sirach 34:13-17).
annotations.2: [18-26] To be acts of true religion, sacrifice and penance must be accompanied by the proper moral dispositions. To offer to God goods taken from the poor ( Sirach 34:18-22), or to practice penance without interior reform, is a mockery, worthless in the sight of God ( Sirach 34:23-26). Cf Matthew 15:4-7; Mark 7:9-13

1.verse: A great anxiety has God allotted, and a heavy yoke, to the sons of men; From the day one leaves his mother's womb to the day he returns to the mother of all the living,

2.verse: His thoughts, the fear in his heart, and his troubled forebodings till the day he dies -

3.verse: Whether he sits on a lofty throne or grovels in dust and ashes,

4.verse: Whether he bears a splendid crown or is wrapped in the coarsest of cloaks -

5.verse: Are of wrath and envy, trouble and dread, terror of death, fury and strife. Even when he lies on his bed to rest, his cares at night disturb his sleep.

6.verse: So short is his rest it seems like none, till in his dreams he struggles as he did by day, Terrified by what his mind's eye sees, like a fugitive being pursued;

7.verse: As he reaches safety, he wakes up astonished that there was nothing to fear.

8.verse: So it is with all flesh, with man and with beast, but for sinners seven times more.

9.verse: Plague and bloodshed, wrath and the sword, plunder and ruin, famine and death:

10.verse: For the wicked, these were created evil, and it is they who bring on destruction.

11.verse: All that is of earth returns to earth, and what is from above returns above.

12.verse: All that comes from bribes or injustice will be wiped out, but loyalty remains for ages.

13.verse: Wealth out of wickedness is like a wadi in spate: like a mighty stream with lightning and thunder,

14.verse: Which, in its rising, rolls along the stones, but suddenly, once and for all, comes to an end.

15.verse: The offshoot of violence will not flourish, for the root of the godless is on sheer rock;

16.verse: Or they are like reeds on the riverbank, withered before all other plants;

17.verse: But goodness will never be cut off, and justice endures forever. Wealth or wages can make life sweet, but better than either is finding a treasure.

18.verse: A child or a city will preserve one's name, but better than either, attaining wisdom.

19.verse: Sheepfolds and orchards bring flourishing health; but better than either, a devoted wife;

20.verse: Wine and music delight the soul, but better than either, conjugal love.

21.verse: The flute and the harp offer sweet melody, but better than either, a voice that is true.

22.verse: Charm and beauty delight the eye, but better than either, the flowers of the field.

23.verse: A friend, a neighbor, are timely guides, but better than either, a prudent wife.

24.verse: A brother, a helper, for times of stress; but better than either, charity that rescues.

25.verse: Gold and silver make one's way secure, but better than either, sound judgment.

26.verse: Wealth and vigor build up confidence, but better than either, fear of God. Fear of the LORD leaves nothing wanting; he who has it need seek no other support:

27.verse: The fear of God is a paradise of blessings; its canopy, all that is glorious.

28.verse: My son, live not the life of a beggar, better to die than to beg;

29.verse: When one has to look to another's table, his life is not really a life. His neighbor's delicacies bring revulsion of spirit to one who understands inward feelings:

30.verse: In the mouth of the shameless man begging is sweet, but within him it burns like fire.

annotations.1: [1-16] The former idyllic description of the universe is contrasted with the picture of the evils afflicting humanity. Every man, high or low, is burdened from birth to death with fears, anxieties and troubles, by day and often by night, the time appointed for rest ( Sirach 40:1-7). For sinners, the suffering is much greater ( Sirach 40:8-10). What they gained by violence and injustice is quickly destroyed; but justice endures forever ( Sirach 40:14-16)
annotations.2: [1] Mother of all the living: the earth from which man was taken. Cf Genesis 2:7; 3:19-20; Job 1:21; Psalm 139:15.
annotations.3: [11] All that is of earth . . . returns above: a reference to bodily mortality and to the divine origin of life from the Spirit of God. Cf Sirach 41:10; Genesis 2:7; 3:19; Job 34:14-15; Psalm 104:29-30; 146:4; Eccl 12:7. The Greek and the Latin render the second half of the verse: "all waters shall return to the sea."
annotations.4: [17-27] Of the many treasures making life sweet, such as health, children, friends, music, vigor, the best are called true conjugal love, wisdom, and above all, fear of God; cf Sirach 25:6-11
annotations.5: [28-30] Among the Jews, beggary was considered degrading to human dignity; it was agreeable only to the shameless, who had lost their sense of honor. Cf Sirach 29:22-23

1.verse: Every friend declares his friendship, but there are friends who are friends in name only.

2.verse: Is it not a sorrow unto death when your bosom companion becomes your enemy?

3.verse: "Alas, my companion! Why were you created to blanket the earth with deceit?"

4.verse: A false friend will share your joys, but in time of trouble he stands afar off.

5.verse: A true friend will fight with you against the foe, against your enemies he will be your shield-bearer.

6.verse: Forget not your comrade during the battle, and neglect him not when you distribute your spoils.

7.verse: Every counselor points out a way, but some counsel ways of their own;

8.verse: Be on the alert when one proffers advice, find out first of all what he wants. For he may be thinking of himself alone; why should the profit fall to him?

9.verse: He may tell you how good your way will be, and then stand by to watch your misfortune.

10.verse: Seek no advice from one who regards you with hostility; from those who envy you, keep your intentions hidden.

11.verse: Speak not to a woman about her rival, nor to a coward about war, to a merchant about business, to a buyer about value, to a miser about generosity, to a cruel man about mercy, to a lazy man about work, to a seasonal laborer about the harvest, to an idle slave about a great task: pay no attention to any advice they give.

12.verse: Instead, associate with a religious man, who you are sure keeps the commandments; Who is like-minded with yourself and will feel for you if you fall.

13.verse: Then, too, heed your own heart's counsel; for what have you that you can depend on more?

14.verse: A man's conscience can tell him his situation better than seven watchmen in a lofty tower.

15.verse: Most important of all, pray to God to set your feet in the path of truth.

16.verse: A word is the source of every deed; a thought, of every act.

17.verse: The root of all conduct is the mind; four branches it shoots forth:

18.verse: Good and evil, death and life, their absolute mistress is the tongue.

19.verse: A man may be wise and benefit many, yet be of no use to himself.

20.verse: Though a man may be wise, if his words are rejected he will be deprived of all enjoyment.

21.verse: When a man is wise to his own advantage, the fruits of his knowledge are seen in his own person;

22.verse: When a man is wise to his people's advantage, the fruits of his knowledge are enduring:

23.verse: Limited are the days of one man's life, but the life of Israel is days without number.

24.verse: One wise for himself has full enjoyment, and all who see him praise him;

25.verse: One wise for his people wins a heritage of glory, and his name endures forever.

26.verse: My son, while you are well, govern your appetite so that you allow it not what is bad for you;

27.verse: For not every food is good for everyone, nor is everything suited to every taste.

28.verse: Be not drawn after every enjoyment, neither become a glutton for choice foods,

29.verse: For sickness comes with overeating, and gluttony brings on biliousness.

30.verse: Through lack of self-control many have died, but the abstemious man prolongs his life.

annotations.1: [16-25] Thoughts determine action. Wisdom is the source of good and life; folly, of evil and death ( Sirach 36:16-18). If the fruits of a man's wisdom benefit himself, he may be praised in his own lifetime; if they benefit his people, his praise endures after him, in their lives ( Sirach 37:19-25).
annotations.2: [26-30] Temperance and self-control should govern a man's appetite for food, which is intended not to destroy but to preserve life

1.verse: All wisdom comes from the LORD and with him it remains forever.

2.verse: The sand of the seashore, the drops of rain, the days of eternity: who can number these?

3.verse: Heaven's height, earth's breadth, the depths of the abyss: who can explore these?

4.verse: Before all things else wisdom was created; and prudent understanding, from eternity.

5.verse: To whom has wisdom's root been revealed? Who knows her subtleties?

6.verse: There is but one, wise and truly awe-inspiring, seated upon his throne:

7.verse: It is the LORD; he created her, has seen her and taken note of her.

8.verse: He has poured her forth upon all his works, upon every living thing according to his bounty; he has lavished her upon his friends.

9.verse: Fear of the LORD is glory and splendor, gladness and a festive crown.

10.verse: Fear of the LORD warms the heart, giving gladness and joy and length of days.

11.verse: He who fears the LORD will have a happy end; even on the day of his death he will be blessed.

12.verse: The beginning of wisdom is fear of the LORD, which is formed with the faithful in the womb.

13.verse: With devoted men was she created from of old, and with their children her beneficence abides.

14.verse: Fullness of wisdom is fear of the LORD; she inebriates men with her fruits.

15.verse: Her entire house she fills with choice foods, her granaries with her harvest.

16.verse: Wisdom's garland is fear of the LORD, with blossoms of peace and perfect health.

17.verse: Knowledge and full understanding she showers down; she heightens the glory of those who possess her.

18.verse: The root of wisdom is fear of the LORD; her branches are length of days.

19.verse: One cannot justify unjust anger; anger plunges a man to his downfall.

20.verse: A patient man need stand firm but for a time, and then contentment comes back to him.

21.verse: For a while he holds back his words, then the lips of many herald his wisdom.

22.verse: Among wisdom's treasures is the paragon of prudence; but fear of the LORD is an abomination to the sinner.

23.verse: If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the LORD will bestow her upon you;

24.verse: For fear of the LORD is wisdom and culture; loyal humility is his delight.

25.verse: Be not faithless to the fear of the LORD, nor approach it with duplicity of heart.

26.verse: Play not the hypocrite before men; over your lips keep watch.

27.verse: Exalt not yourself lest you fall and bring upon you dishonor;

28.verse: For then the LORD will reveal your secrets and publicly cast you down,

29.verse: Because you approached the fear of the LORD with your heart full of guile.

annotations.1: [1-8] The Lord is the source and preserver of wisdom ( Sirach 1:1); he created her from eternity, before all things else ( Sirach 1:4-7); all his works reflect wisdom ( Sirach 1:2, 3, 8)
annotations.2: [1] Wisdom: here the author speaks of true wisdom, namely God's external revelation of himself. Throughout the book he describes in great detail just what wisdom is; sometimes it is divine; sometimes it is a synonym for God's law; sometimes it is human. But the author makes clear that even human wisdom, properly understood, comes from God.
annotations.3: [9-18] Here are described the spiritual and temporal blessings that come during the lifetime of him who fears the Lord, i.e., practices true religion
annotations.4: [9] Fear of the LORD: see note on Psalm 111:10
annotations.5: [19-22] The disciple of wisdom shuns unjust anger which brings downfall. By patience and self-control he preserves calm, recovers contentment, and receives public praise. The sinner, on the contrary, despises the restraints which religion imposes
annotations.6: [25-29] Infidelity to religion, or the use of it for any but the single purpose of serving God, is hypocrisy and self-exaltation, deserving of public disgrace

1.verse: Children, pay heed to a father's right; do so that you may live.

2.verse: For the LORD sets a father in honor over his children; a mother's authority he confirms over her sons.

3.verse: He who honors his father atones for sins;

4.verse: he stores up riches who reveres his mother.

5.verse: He who honors his father is gladdened by children, and when he prays he is heard.

6.verse: He who reveres his father will live a long life; he obeys the LORD who brings comfort to his mother.

7.verse: He who fears the LORD honors his father, and serves his parents as rulers.

8.verse: In word and deed honor your father that his blessing may come upon you;

9.verse: For a father's blessing gives a family firm roots, but a mother's curse uproots the growing plant.

10.verse: Glory not in your father's shame, for his shame is no glory to you!

11.verse: His father's honor is a man's glory; disgrace for her children, a mother's shame.

12.verse: My son, take care of your father when he is old; grieve him not as long as he lives.

13.verse: Even if his mind fail, be considerate with him; revile him not in the fullness of your strength.

14.verse: For kindness to a father will not be forgotten, it will serve as a sin offering - it will take lasting root.

15.verse: In time of tribulation it will be recalled to your advantage, like warmth upon frost it will melt away your sins.

16.verse: A blasphemer is he who despises his father; accursed of his Creator, he who angers his mother.

17.verse: My son, conduct your affairs with humility, and you will be loved more than a giver of gifts.

18.verse: Humble yourself the more, the greater you are, and you will find favor with God.

19.verse: For great is the power of God; by the humble he is glorified.

20.verse: What is too sublime for you, seek not, into things beyond your strength search not.

21.verse: What is committed to you, attend to; for what is hidden is not your concern.

22.verse: With what is too much for you meddle not, when shown things beyond human understanding.

23.verse: Their own opinion has misled many, and false reasoning unbalanced their judgment.

24.verse: Where the pupil of the eye is missing, there is no light, and where there is no knowledge, there is no wisdom.

25.verse: A stubborn man will fare badly in the end, and he who loves danger will perish in it.

26.verse: A stubborn man will be burdened with sorrow; a sinner will heap sin upon sin.

27.verse: For the affliction of the proud man there is no cure; he is the offshoot of an evil plant.

28.verse: The mind of a sage appreciates proverbs, and an attentive ear is the wise man's joy.

29.verse: Water quenches a flaming fire, and alms atone for sins.

30.verse: He who does a kindness is remembered afterward; when he falls, he finds a support.

annotations.1: [1-16] Besides the virtues that must characterize our conduct toward God, special duties toward our neighbor are enjoined, such as honor and respect toward parents, with corresponding blessings ( Sirach 3:1-9). Even to old and infirm parents this respect is due ( Sirach 3:10-13); through it, the sins of children are pardoned ( Sirach 3:14, 15). Failure to render respect is blasphemy and merits a curse from God ( Sirach 3:16). Cf Exodus 20:12; Eph 6:2-3.
annotations.2: [17-27] Humility gives a true estimate of self ( Sirach 3:17-19). Through it a man performs duty, avoids what is beyond his understanding and strength ( Sirach 3:20-22). Pride, however, begets false greatness, misjudgment, stubborness, sorrow, affliction and perdition ( Sirach 3:23-27)
annotations.3: [19] An alternate or additional line would read: "For though many have been great in the course of time, it is to the humble he reveals his secrets." Cf Matthew 11:25-26; 1 Cor 1:26-29
annotations.4: [29- 4:10] Mercy and kindness toward those in misfortune atone for sin and endear a man to God and to his fellow men

1.verse: To keep the law is a great oblation, and he who observes the commandments sacrifices a peace offering.

2.verse: In works of charity one offers fine flour, and when he gives alms he presents his sacrifice of praise.

3.verse: To refrain from evil pleases the LORD, and to avoid injustice is an atonement.

4.verse: Appear not before the LORD empty-handed, for all that you offer is in fulfillment of the precepts.

5.verse: The just man's offering enriches the altar and rises as a sweet odor before the Most High.

6.verse: The just man's sacrifice is most pleasing, nor will it ever be forgotten.

7.verse: In generous spirit pay homage to the LORD, be not sparing of freewill gifts.

8.verse: With each contribution show a cheerful countenance, and pay your tithes in a spirit of joy.

9.verse: Give to the Most High as he has given to you, generously, according to your means.

10.verse: For the LORD is one who always repays, and he will give back to you sevenfold.

11.verse: But offer no bribes, these he does not accept! Trust not in sacrifice of the fruits of extortion,

12.verse: For he is a God of justice, who knows no favorites.

13.verse: Though not unduly partial toward the weak, yet he hears the cry of the oppressed.

14.verse: He is not deaf to the wail of the orphan, nor to the widow when she pours out her complaint;

15.verse: Do not the tears that stream down her cheek cry out against him that causes them to fall?

16.verse: He who serves God willingly is heard; his petition reaches the heavens.

17.verse: The prayer of the lowly pierces the clouds; it does not rest till it reaches its goal,

18.verse: Nor will it withdraw till the Most High responds, judges justly and affirms the right.

19.verse: God indeed will not delay, and like a warrior, will not be still

20.verse: Till he breaks the backs of the merciless and wreaks vengeance upon the proud;

21.verse: Till he destroys the haughty root and branch, and smashes the scepter of the wicked;

22.verse: Till he requites mankind according to its deeds, and repays men according to their thoughts;

23.verse: Till he defends the cause of his people, and gladdens them by his mercy.

24.verse: Welcome is his mercy in time of distress as rain clouds in time of drought

annotations.1: [1-24] Keeping the commandments of the law and avoiding injustice constitute sacrifice pleasing and acceptable to God ( Sirach 35:1-3). Offerings also should be made to him, cheerfully and generously; these he repays . . . sevenfold ( Sirach 35:4-10). Extortion from widows and orphans is injustice, which God quickly repays ( Sirach 35:11-18). Punishing the proud and the merciless and coming to the aid of the distressed, he requites all according to their deeds ( Sirach 35:19-24).
annotations.2: [2] Fine flour, together with oil and frankincense, was a prescribed offering to God; cf Lev 2:1-3

1.verse: A wise magistrate lends stability to his people, and the government of a prudent man is well ordered.

2.verse: As the people's judge, so are his ministers; as the head of a city, its inhabitants.

3.verse: A wanton king destroys his people, but a city grows through the wisdom of its princes.

4.verse: Sovereignty over the earth is in the hand of God, who raises up on it the man of the hour;

5.verse: Sovereignty over every man is in the hand of God, who imparts his majesty to the ruler.

6.verse: No matter the wrong, do no violence to your neighbor, and do not walk the path of arrogance.

7.verse: Odious to the LORD and to men is arrogance, and the sin of oppression they both hate.

8.verse: Dominion is transferred from one people to another because of the violence of the arrogant.

9.verse: Why are dust and ashes proud? even during life man's body decays;

10.verse: A slight illness - the doctor jests, a king today - tomorrow he is dead.

11.verse: When a man dies, he inherits corruption; worms and gnats and maggots.

12.verse: The beginning of pride is man's stubbornness in withdrawing his heart from his Maker;

13.verse: For pride is the reservoir of sin, a source which runs over with vice; Because of it God sends unheard-of afflictions and brings men to utter ruin.

14.verse: The thrones of the arrogant God overturns and establishes the lowly in their stead.

15.verse: The roots of the proud God plucks up, to plant the humble in their place:

16.verse: He breaks down their stem to the level of the ground, then digs their roots from the earth.

17.verse: The traces of the proud God sweeps away and effaces the memory of them from the earth.

18.verse: Insolence is not allotted to a man, nor stubborn anger to one born of woman.

19.verse: Whose offspring can be in honor? Those of men. Which offspring are in honor? Those who fear God. Whose offspring can be in disgrace? Those of men. Which offspring are in disgrace? Those who transgress the commandments.

20.verse: Among brethren their leader is in honor; he who fears God is in honor among his people.

21.verse: Be it tenant or wayfarer, alien or pauper, his glory is the fear of the LORD.

22.verse: It is not just to despise a man who is wise but poor, nor proper to honor any sinner.

23.verse: The prince, the ruler, the judge are in honor; but none is greater than he who fears God.

24.verse: When free men serve a prudent slave, the wise man does not complain.

25.verse: Flaunt not your wisdom in managing your affairs, and boast not in your time of need.

26.verse: Better the worker who has plenty of everything than the boaster who is without bread.

27.verse: My son, with humility have self-esteem; prize yourself as you deserve.

28.verse: Who will acquit him who condemns himself? who will honor him who discredits himself?

29.verse: The poor man is honored for his wisdom as the rich man is honored for his wealth;

30.verse: Honored in poverty, how much more so in wealth! Dishonored in wealth, in poverty how much the more!

annotations.1: [6-18] Glory displayed through arrogance and pride is false and displeasing to God and men, because founded on dust and ashes ( Sirach 10:6-11). It is the denial of the glory due to God, and therefore the source of all sin ( Sirach 10:12-13). Even the memory of the proud is destroyed and God transfers their power to the lowly ( Sirach 10:14-18).
annotations.2: [9-10] The text is uncertain. Its general implication is that man deteriorates physically even while alive: a slight illness today may be followed by death tomorrow. The uncertainty of life leaves no room for pride
annotations.3: [19- 11:6] Regardless of social barriers, genuine honor among men comes from fear of the Lord and a true estimate of self. The Lord exalts the lowly and oppressed; transgressors of the commandments merit dishonor and disgrace

1.verse: The LORD from the earth created man, and in his own image he made him.

2.verse: Limited days of life he gives him and makes him return to earth again.

3.verse: He endows man with a strength of his own, and with power over all things else on earth.

4.verse: He puts the fear of him in all flesh, and gives him rule over beasts and birds.

5.verse: He forms men's tongues and eyes and ears, and imparts to them an understanding heart.

6.verse: With wisdom and knowledge he fills them; good and evil he shows them.

7.verse: He looks with favor upon their hearts, and shows them his glorious works,

8.verse: That they may describe the wonders of his deeds and praise his holy name.

9.verse: He has set before them knowledge, a law of life as their inheritance;

10.verse: An everlasting covenant he has made with them, his commandments he has revealed to them.

11.verse: His majestic glory their eyes beheld, his glorious voice their ears heard.

12.verse: He says to them, "Avoid all evil"; each of them he gives precepts about his fellow men.

13.verse: Their ways are ever known to him, they cannot be hidden from his eyes.

14.verse: Over every nation he places a ruler, but the LORD'S own portion is Israel.

15.verse: All their actions are clear as the sun to him, his eyes are ever upon their ways.

16.verse: Their wickedness cannot be hidden from him; all of their sins are before the LORD.

17.verse: A man's goodness God cherishes like a signet ring, a man's virtue, like the apple of his eye.

18.verse: Later he will rise up and repay them, and requite each one of them as they deserve.

19.verse: But to the penitent he provides a way back, he encourages those who are losing hope!

20.verse: Return to the LORD and give up sin, pray to him and make your offenses few.

21.verse: Turn again to the Most High and away from sin, hate intensely what he loathes;

22.verse: Who in the nether world can glorify the Most High in place of the living who offer their praise?

23.verse: No more can the dead give praise than those who have never lived; they glorify the LORD who are alive and well.

24.verse: How great the mercy of the LORD, his forgiveness of those who return to him!

25.verse: The like cannot be found in men, for not immortal is any son of man.

26.verse: Is anything brighter than the sun? Yet it can be eclipsed. How obscure then the thoughts of flesh and blood!

27.verse: God watches over the hosts of highest heaven, while all men are dust and ashes.

annotations.1: [10] An everlasting covenant . . . his commandments: the various covenants which God entered into with mankind, e.g., Genesis 2:15-17; 17:1-22 especially on Mount Sinai where the people saw God's glory and heard his voice ( Exodus 19:16- 24:18).
annotations.2: [14] Ruler: this may refer to civil authority or to angels placed over nations as guardians; see note on Deut 32:8 and the cross references above
annotations.3: [19-27] Exhorting the sinner to return to God ( Sirach 17:19-21, 24-26) the author implies that the Lord will postpone death for a repentant sinner so that he may fulfill his destiny of praising God on earth ( Sirach 17:22-23). In the light of Christian teaching, the gift of final penitence extends this divine purpose into life everlasting. See note on Psalm 6:6; cf also Ezekiel 18:23; 33:11-16
annotations.4: [26] Obscure: literally, evil; compare Genesis 6:5. Though moral fault is not excluded, the thought here is the inability to understand the merciful designs of God. Cf Wisdom 9:14-18

1.verse: My son, rob not the poor man of his livelihood; force not the eyes of the needy to turn away.

2.verse: A hungry man grieve not, a needy man anger not;

3.verse: Do not exasperate the downtrodden; delay not to give to the needy.

4.verse: A beggar in distress do not reject; avert not your face from the poor.

5.verse: From the needy turn not your eyes, give no man reason to curse you;

6.verse: For if in the bitterness of his soul he curse you, his Creator will hear his prayer.

7.verse: Endear yourself to the assembly; before a ruler bow your head.

8.verse: Give a hearing to the poor man, and return his greeting with courtesy;

9.verse: Deliver the oppressed from the hand of the oppressor; let not justice be repugnant to you.

10.verse: To the fatherless be as a father, and help their mother as a husband would; Thus will you be like a son to the Most High, and he will be more tender to you than a mother.

11.verse: Wisdom instructs her children and admonishes those who seek her.

12.verse: He who loves her loves life; those who seek her out win her favor.

13.verse: He who holds her fast inherits glory; wherever he dwells, the LORD bestows blessings.

14.verse: Those who serve her serve the Holy One; those who love her the LORD loves.

15.verse: He who obeys her judges nations; he who hearkens to her dwells in her inmost chambers.

16.verse: If one trusts her, he will possess her; his descendants too will inherit her.

17.verse: She walks with him as a stranger, and at first she puts him to the test; Fear and dread she brings upon him and tries him with her discipline; With her precepts she puts him to the proof, until his heart is fully with her.

18.verse: Then she comes back to bring him happiness and reveal her secrets to him.

19.verse: But if he fails her, she will abandon him and deliver him into the hands of despoilers.

20.verse: Use your time well; guard yourself from evil, and bring upon yourself no shame.

21.verse: There is a sense of shame laden with guilt, and a shame that merits honor and respect.

22.verse: Show no favoritism to your own discredit; let no one intimidate you to your own downfall.

23.verse: Refrain not from speaking at the proper time, and hide not away your wisdom;

24.verse: For it is through speech that wisdom becomes known, and knowledge through the tongue's rejoinder.

25.verse: Never gainsay the truth, and struggle not against the rushing stream.

26.verse: Be not ashamed to acknowledge your guilt, but of your ignorance rather be ashamed.

27.verse: Do not abase yourself before an impious man, nor refuse to do so before rulers.

28.verse: Even to the death fight for truth, and the LORD your God will battle for you.

29.verse: Be not surly in your speech, nor lazy and slack in your deeds.

30.verse: Be not a lion at home, nor sly and suspicious at work.

31.verse: Let not your hand be open to receive and clenched when it is time to give.

annotations.1: [1] Eyes of the needy: when they look for help; cf Sirach 18:17.
annotations.2: [11-19] The Hebrew text presents wisdom speaking in the first person, as in Sirach 24. The precious fruits of wisdom: life, favor, glory, blessings, God's love, are intended to arouse desire for her ( Sirach 4:11-14). Her disciples are like priests ( Sirach 4:14) and judges ( Sirach 4:15), even partners who possess her for themselves and their descendants ( Sirach 4:16). They enjoy happiness and penetrate her profound secrets after surviving her tests ( Sirach 4:17, 18). Those who fail her are abandoned to destruction ( Sirach 4:19)
annotations.3: [20-31] Besides the interior trials of discipline and precept, the disciple of wisdom is warned against external dangers to his sincerity and justice, namely evil, human respect ( Sirach 4:20, 21), compromise of liberty in speech and action ( Sirach 4:22-25), false shame, and ignorance ( Sirach 4:26). He must fight for the truth ( Sirach 4:28), and avoid cynicism and laziness ( Sirach 4:29), and inconsistency in his conduct ( Sirach 4:30)

1.verse: The name JOSIAH is like blended incense, made lasting by a skilled perfumer. Precious is his memory, like honey to the taste, like music at a banquet.

2.verse: For he grieved over our betrayals, and destroyed the abominable idols.

3.verse: He turned to God with his whole heart, and, though times were evil, he practiced virtue.

4.verse: Except for David, Hezekiah and Josiah, they all were wicked; They abandoned the Law of the Most High, these kings of Judah, right to the very end.

5.verse: So he gave over their power to others, their glory to a foolish foreign nation

6.verse: Who burned the holy city and left its streets desolate, As JEREMIAH had foretold;

7.verse: for they had treated him badly who even in the womb had been made a prophet, To root out, pull down, and destroy, and then to build and to plant.

8.verse: EZEKIEL beheld the vision and described the different creatures of the chariot;

9.verse: He also referred to JOB, who always persevered in the right path.

10.verse: Then, too, the TWELVE PROPHETS - may their bones return to life from their resting place! - Gave new strength to Jacob and saved him by their faith and hope.

11.verse: How can we fittingly praise ZERUBBABEL, who was like a signet ring on God's right hand,

12.verse: And Jeshua, Jozadak's son? In their time they built the house of God; They erected the holy temple, destined for everlasting glory.

13.verse: Extolled be the memory of NEHEMIAH! He rebuilt our ruined walls, Restored our shattered defenses, and set up gates and bars.

14.verse: Few on earth have been made the equal of ENOCH, for he was taken up bodily.

15.verse: Was ever a man born like JOSEPH? Even his dead body was provided for.

16.verse: Glorious, too, were SHEM and SETH and ENOS; but beyond that of any living being was the splendor of ADAM.

annotations.1: [1-10] The author's praise of King Josiah ( Sirach 49:1-3), of the prophets Jeremiah and Ezekiel and likewise the minor prophets ( Sirach 49:7-10) derives from their spirit of fidelity to the Lord and his law amid the infidelity of kings and people ( Sirach 49:4-6, 10).
annotations.2: [11-13] Zerubbabel and Jeshua, in rebuilding the temple, and Nehemiah, the governor, in repairing the walls of the Holy City also restored what these constructions signify, namely, religious worship and civil authority as prescribed in the law
annotations.3: [14-16] The patriarchs here mentioned were glorious because of their spirit of religion, i.e., their profound reverence for God and obedience to him. The splendor of Adam, moreover, was due to his direct origin from God

1.verse: He who touches pitch blackens his hand; he who associates with an impious man learns his ways.

2.verse: Bear no burden too heavy for you; go with no one greater or wealthier than yourself. How can the earthen pot go with the metal cauldron? When they knock together, the pot will be smashed:

3.verse: The rich man does wrong and boasts of it, the poor man is wronged and begs forgiveness.

4.verse: As long as the rich man can use you he will enslave you, but when you are exhausted, he will abandon you.

5.verse: As long as you have anything he will speak fair words to you, and with smiles he will win your confidence;

6.verse: When he needs something from you he will cajole you, then without regret he will impoverish you.

7.verse: While it serves his purpose he will beguile you, then twice or three times he will terrify you; When later he sees you he will pass you by, and shake his head over you.

8.verse: Guard against being presumptuous; be not as those who lack sense.

9.verse: When invited by a man of influence, keep your distance; then he will urge you all the more.

10.verse: Be not bold with him lest you be rebuffed, but keep not too far away lest you be forgotten.

11.verse: Engage not freely in discussion with him, trust not his many words; For by prolonged talk he will test you, and though smiling he will probe you.

12.verse: Mercilessly he will make of you a laughingstock, and will not refrain from injury or chains.

13.verse: Be on your guard and take care never to accompany men of violence.

14.verse: Every living thing loves its own kind, every man a man like himself.

15.verse: Every being is drawn to its own kind; with his own kind every man associates.

16.verse: Is a wolf ever allied with a lamb? So it is with the sinner and the just.

17.verse: Can there be peace between the hyena and the dog? Or between the rich and the poor can there be peace?

18.verse: Lion's prey are the wild asses of the desert; so too the poor are feeding grounds for the rich.

19.verse: A proud man abhors lowliness; so does the rich man abhor the poor.

20.verse: When a rich man stumbles he is supported by a friend; when a poor man trips he is pushed down by a friend.

21.verse: Many are the supporters for a rich man when he speaks; though what he says is odious, it wins approval. When a poor man speaks they make sport of him; he speaks wisely and no attention is paid him.

22.verse: A rich man speaks and all are silent, his wisdom they extol to the clouds. A poor man speaks and they say: "Who is that?" If he slips they cast him down.

23.verse: Wealth is good when there is no sin; but poverty is evil by the standards of the proud.

24.verse: The heart of a man changes his countenance, either for good or for evil.

25.verse: The sign of a good heart is a cheerful countenance; withdrawn and perplexed is the laborious schemer

annotations.1: [1- 14:2] By means of various figures Sirach indicates the practical impossibility of genuine and sincere companionship between the poor and the proud rich. He lays down the principle of associating with equals ( Sirach 13:15).
annotations.2: [17] The hostility between the dogs which guard the flocks at night and the rapacious hyenas is proverbial in Palestine

1.verse: An admonition can be inopportune, and a man may be wise to hold his peace.

2.verse: It is much better to admonish than to lose one's temper, for one who admits his fault will be kept from disgrace.

3.verse: Like a eunuch lusting for intimacy with a maiden is he who does right under compulsion.

4.verse: One man is silent and is thought wise, another is talkative and is disliked.

5.verse: One man is silent because he has nothing to say; another is silent, biding his time.

6.verse: A wise man is silent till the right time comes, but a boasting fool ignores the proper time.

7.verse: He who talks too much is detested; he who pretends to authority is hated.

8.verse: Some misfortunes bring success; some things gained are a man's loss.

9.verse: Some gifts do one no good, and some must be paid back double.

10.verse: Humiliation can follow fame, while from obscurity a man can lift up his head.

11.verse: A man may buy much for little, but pay for it seven times over.

12.verse: A wise man makes himself popular by a few words, but fools pour forth their blandishments in vain.

13.verse: A gift from a rogue will do you no good, for in his eyes his one gift is equal to seven.

14.verse: He gives little and criticizes often, and like a crier he shouts aloud. He lends today, he asks it back tomorrow; hateful indeed is such a man.

15.verse: A fool has no friends, nor thanks for his generosity;

16.verse: Those who eat his bread have an evil tongue. How many times they laugh him to scorn!

17.verse: A fall to the ground is less sudden than a slip of the tongue; that is why the downfall of the wicked comes so quickly.

18.verse: Insipid food is the untimely tale; the unruly are always ready to offer it.

19.verse: A proverb when spoken by a fool is unwelcome, for he does not utter it at the proper time.

20.verse: A man through want may be unable to sin, yet in this tranquility he cannot rest.

21.verse: One may lose his life through shame, and perish through a fool's intimidation.

22.verse: A man makes a promise to a friend out of shame, and has him for his enemy needlessly.

23.verse: A lie is a foul blot in a man, yet it is constantly on the lips of the unruly.

24.verse: Better a thief than an inveterate liar, yet both will suffer disgrace;

25.verse: A liar's way leads to dishonor, his shame remains ever with him.

26.verse: A wise man advances himself by his words, a prudent man pleases the great.

27.verse: He who works his land has abundant crops, he who pleases the great is pardoned his faults.

28.verse: Favors and gifts blind the eyes; like a muzzle over the mouth they silence reproof.

29.verse: Hidden wisdom and unseen treasure - of what value is either?

30.verse: Better the man who hides his folly than the one who hides his wisdom.

annotations.1: [1-7] Wisdom indicates the proper times for speech and silence, that is, the occasions when the most benefit can be gained from them.
annotations.2: [3] The sense is that violence or force against a person can prevent an external act of sin or compel a good deed without eliminating the internal sin or desire of wrongdoing. Cf Sirach 20:20
annotations.3: [8-16] In a series of paradoxes the author indicates how much true and lasting values differ from apparent ones
annotations.4: [9] And some . . . double: or perhaps, "but some are doubly precious."
annotations.5: [17-25] The ill-timed speech of the wicked, the unruly and a fool is repulsive ( Sirach 20:17-19); human respect exposes one to intimidation, rash promises and enmity ( Sirach 20:21- 22); lies bring dishonor and lasting disgrace ( Sirach 20:23, 24, 25)
annotations.6: [26-30] Unlike the fool who invites disaster through misuse of his tongue, the sage through prudent speech gains in honor and esteem among the great ( Sirach 20:26-27). He must beware, however, of accepting bribes, lest he share in evil through silence when he should reprove ( Sirach 20:28-30)

1.verse: The clear vault of the sky shines forth like heaven itself, a vision of glory.

2.verse: The orb of the sun, resplendent at its rising: what a wonderful work of the Most High!

3.verse: At noon it seethes the surface of the earth, and who can bear its fiery heat?

4.verse: Like a blazing furnace of solid metal, it sets the mountains aflame with its rays; By its fiery darts the land is consumed; the eyes are dazzled by its light.

5.verse: Great indeed is the LORD who made it, at whose orders it urges on its steeds.

6.verse: The moon, too, that marks the changing times, governing the seasons, their lasting sign,

7.verse: By which we know the feast days and fixed dates, this light-giver which wanes in its course:

8.verse: As its name says, each month it renews itself; how wondrous in this change!

9.verse: The beauty, the glory, of the heavens are the stars that adorn with their sparkling the heights of God,

10.verse: At whose command they keep their place and never relax in their vigils. A weapon against the flood waters stored on high, lighting up the firmament by its brilliance,

11.verse: Behold the rainbow! Then bless its Maker, for majestic indeed is its splendor;

12.verse: It spans the heavens with its glory, this bow bent by the mighty hand of God.

13.verse: His rebuke marks out the path for the lightning, and speeds the arrows of his judgment to their goal.

14.verse: At it the storehouse is opened, and like vultures the clouds hurry forth.

15.verse: In his majesty he gives the storm its power and breaks off the hailstones.

16.verse: The thunder of his voice makes the earth writhe; before his might the mountains quake.

17.verse: A word from him drives on the south wind, the angry north wind, the hurricane and the storm.

18.verse: He sprinkles the snow like fluttering birds; it comes to settle like swarms of locusts.

19.verse: Its shining whiteness blinds the eyes, the mind is baffled by its steady fall.

20.verse: He scatters frost like so much salt; it shines like blossoms on the thornbush.

21.verse: Cold northern blasts he sends that turn the ponds to lumps of ice. He freezes over every body of water, and clothes each pool with a coat of mail.

22.verse: When the mountain growth is scorched with heat, and the flowering plains as though by flames,

23.verse: The dripping clouds restore them all, and the scattered dew enriches the parched land.

24.verse: His is the plan that calms the deep, and plants the islands in the sea.

25.verse: Those who go down to the sea tell part of its story, and when we hear them we are thunderstruck;

26.verse: In it are his creatures, stupendous, amazing, all kinds of life, and the monsters of the deep.

27.verse: For him each messenger succeeds, and at his bidding accomplishes his will.

28.verse: More than this we need not add; let the last word be, he is all in all!

29.verse: Let us praise him the more, since we cannot fathom him, for greater is he than all his works;

30.verse: Awful indeed is the LORD'S majesty, and wonderful is his power.

31.verse: Lift up your voices to glorify the LORD, though he is still beyond your power to praise;

32.verse: Extol him with renewed strength, and weary not, though you cannot reach the end:

33.verse: For who can see him and describe him? or who can praise him as he is?

34.verse: Beyond these, many things lie hid; only a few of his works have we seen.

35.verse: It is the LORD who has made all things, and to those who fear him he gives wisdom.

annotations.1: [28] All in all: the perfections reflected in creation are found in a transcendent way in God, who alone is their source.

1.verse: The poor man's wisdom lifts his head high and sets him among princes.

2.verse: Praise not a man for his looks; despise not a man for his appearance.

3.verse: Least is the bee among winged things, but she reaps the choicest of all harvests.

4.verse: Mock not the worn cloak and jibe at no man's bitter day: For strange are the works of the LORD, hidden from men his deeds.

5.verse: The oppressed often rise to a throne, and some that none would consider wear a crown.

6.verse: The exalted often fall into utter disgrace; the honored are given into enemy hands.

7.verse: Before investigating, find no fault; examine first, then criticize.

8.verse: Before hearing, answer not, and interrupt no one in the middle of his speech.

9.verse: Dispute not about what is not your concern; in the strife of the arrogant take no part.

10.verse: My son, why increase your cares, since he who is avid for wealth will not be blameless? Even if you run after it, you will never overtake it; however you seek it, you will not find it.

11.verse: One may toil and struggle and drive, and fall short all the more.

12.verse: Another goes his way a weakling and a failure, with little strength and great misery - Yet the eyes of the LORD look favorably upon him; he raises him free of the vile dust,

13.verse: Lifts up his head and exalts him to the amazement of the many.

14.verse: Good and evil, life and death, poverty and riches, are from the LORD.

15.verse: Wisdom and understanding and knowledge of affairs, love and virtuous paths are from the LORD.

16.verse: Error and darkness were formed with sinners from their birth, and evil grows old with evildoers.

17.verse: The LORD'S gift remains with the just; his favor brings continued success.

18.verse: A man may become rich through a miser's life, and this is his allotted reward:

19.verse: When he says: "I have found rest, now I will feast on my possessions," He does not know how long it will be till he dies and leaves them to others.

20.verse: My son, hold fast to your duty, busy yourself with it, grow old while doing your task.

21.verse: Admire not how sinners live, but trust in the LORD and wait for his light; For it is easy with the LORD suddenly, in an instant, to make a poor man rich.

22.verse: God's blessing is the lot of the just man, and in due time his hopes bear fruit.

23.verse: Say not: "What do I need? What further pleasure can be mine?"

24.verse: Say not: "I am independent. What harm can come to me now?"

25.verse: The day of prosperity makes one forget adversity; the day of adversity makes one forget prosperity.

26.verse: For it is easy with the LORD on the day of death to repay man according to his deeds.

27.verse: A moment's affliction brings forgetfulness of past delights; when a man dies, his life is revealed.

28.verse: Call no man happy before his death, for by how he ends, a man is known.

29.verse: Bring not every man into your house, for many are the snares of the crafty one;

30.verse: Though he seem like a bird confined in a cage, yet like a spy he will pick out the weak spots.

31.verse: The talebearer turns good into evil; with a spark he sets many coals afire.

32.verse: The evil man lies in wait for blood, and plots against your choicest possessions.

33.verse: Avoid a wicked man, for he breeds only evil, lest you incur a lasting stain.

34.verse: Lodge a stranger with you, and he will subvert your course, and make a stranger of you to your own household.

annotations.2: [7-25] Discretion regulates a man's conduct toward others and their affairs ( Sirach 11:7-9); as regards his own interests, a man should avoid solicitude for the passing external benefits of life and property ( Sirach 11:10-14, 18, 19, 21, 23-25) and cultivate the lasting inward gifts of wisdom and virtue ( Sirach 11:15, 17, 20, 22)
annotations.3: [14] Divine Providence ultimately governs the lives of men. Evil: misfortune and calamity sent by God either in punishment or as an incentive to repentance or to greater virtue
annotations.4: [15-16] Some ancient witnesses omit these two verses
annotations.5: [19] Cf the parable of the rich man, Luke 12:16-21
annotations.6: [26-28] Sirach, writing before Christian revelation, did not go beyond the hour of death to find full divine retribution

1.verse: LORD, Father and Master of my life, permit me not to fall by them!

2.verse: Who will apply the lash to my thoughts, to my mind the rod of discipline, That my failings may not be spared, nor the sins of my heart overlooked;

3.verse: Lest my failings increase, and my sins be multiplied; Lest I succumb to my foes, and my enemy rejoice over me?

4.verse: LORD, Father and God of my life, abandon me not into their control!

5.verse: A brazen look allow me not; ward off passion from my heart,

6.verse: Let not the lustful cravings of the flesh master me, surrender me not to shameless desires.

7.verse: Give heed, my children, to the instruction that I pronounce, for he who keeps it will not be enslaved.

8.verse: Through his lips is the sinner ensnared; the railer and the arrogant man fall thereby.

9.verse: Let not your mouth form the habit of swearing, or becoming too familiar with the Holy Name.

10.verse: Just as a slave that is constantly under scrutiny will not be without welts, So one who swears continually by the Holy Name will not remain free from sin.

11.verse: A man who often swears heaps up obligations; the scourge will never be far from his house. If he swears in error, he incurs guilt; if he neglects his obligation, his sin is doubly great. If he swears without reason he cannot be found just, and all his house will suffer affliction.

12.verse: There are words which merit death; may they never be heard among Jacob's heirs. For all such words are foreign to the devout, who do not wallow in sin.

13.verse: Let not your mouth become used to coarse talk, for in it lies sinful matter.

14.verse: Keep your father and mother in mind when you sit among the mighty, Lest in their presence you commit a blunder and disgrace your upbringing, By wishing you had never been born or cursing the day of your birth.

15.verse: A man who has the habit of abusive language will never mature in character as long as he lives.

16.verse: Two types of men multiply sins, a third draws down wrath; For burning passion is a blazing fire, not to be quenched till it burns itself out: A man given to sins of the flesh, who never stops until the fire breaks forth;

17.verse: The rake to whom all bread is sweet and who is never through till he dies;

18.verse: And the man who dishonors his marriage bed and says to himself "Who can see me? Darkness surrounds me, walls hide me; no one sees me; why should I fear to sin?" Of the Most High he is not mindful,

19.verse: fearing only the eyes of men; He does not understand that the eyes of the LORD, ten thousand times brighter than the sun, Observe every step a man takes and peer into hidden corners.

20.verse: He who knows all things before they exist still knows them all after they are made.

21.verse: Such a man will be punished in the streets of the city; when he least expects it, he will be apprehended.

22.verse: So also with the woman who is unfaithful to her husband and offers as heir her son by a stranger.

23.verse: First, she has disobeyed the law of the Most High; secondly, she has wronged her husband; Thirdly, in her wanton adultery she has borne children by another man.

24.verse: Such a woman will be dragged before the assembly, and her punishment will extend to her children;

25.verse: Her children will not take root; her branches will not bring forth fruit.

26.verse: She will leave an accursed memory; her disgrace will never be blotted out.

27.verse: Thus all who dwell on the earth shall know, and all who inhabit the world shall understand, That nothing is better than the fear of the LORD, nothing more salutary than to obey his commandments.

annotations.1: [1] LORD, Father and Master of my life: these words express the tender personal relationship between the author's soul and God, the need of his assistance, and the truth of his providence.
annotations.2: [7-15] A warning against sins of the tongue through misuse of the Holy Name, thoughtless swearing which involves obligation and incurs guilt ( Sirach 23:7-11), blasphemy ( Sirach 23:12), talk that is coarse and blundersome ( Sirach 23:13, 14), and the incorrigible habit of abusive language ( Sirach 23:15)
annotations.3: [10] As a slave . . . under scrutiny, so is he who calls on God to witness the truth of what he says
annotations.4: [16-27] From sins of the tongue the author proceeds to treat of sins of the flesh and their dire consequences. The passion of lust tyrannizes over its victims and, like fire, consumes and utterly destroys them ( Sirach 23:16, 17, 22-26). The false security of the adulterer serves but to aggravate his inevitable fate ( Sirach 23:18-21). Only the fear of the Lord and observance of his commandments can assure moral safety ( Sirach 23:27)
annotations.5: [16] Two types . . . a third: three kinds of sins of impurity, with increasing degrees of gravity: solitary sins ( Sirach 23:16) fornication ( Sirach 23:17) and adultery ( Sirach 23:18-21)
annotations.7: [23] The detailed evil of adultery includes disobedience to God's law ( Exodus 20:14), injustice to a partner in marriage, and disgraceful offspring
annotations.8: [24-25] The judgment of the assembly determined the illegitimacy of children born of adultery or incest and excluded them from the "community of the LORD" ( Deut 23:3). Cf Wisdom 3:16-19; 4:3-6

1.verse: He who loves his son chastises him often, that he may be his joy when he grows up.

2.verse: He who disciplines his son will benefit from him, and boast of him among his intimates.

3.verse: He who educates his son makes his enemy jealous, and shows his delight in him among his friends.

4.verse: At the father's death, he will seem not dead, since he leaves after him one like himself,

5.verse: Whom he looks upon through life with joy, and even in death, without regret:

6.verse: The avenger he leaves against his foes, and the one to repay his friends with kindness.

7.verse: He who spoils his son will have wounds to bandage, and will quake inwardly at every outcry.

8.verse: A colt untamed turns out stubborn; a son left to himself grows up unruly.

9.verse: Pamper your child and he will be a terror for you, indulge him and he will bring you grief.

10.verse: Share not in his frivolity lest you share in his sorrow, when finally your teeth are clenched in remorse.

11.verse: Give him not his own way in his youth, and close not your eyes to his follies.

12.verse: Bend him to the yoke when he is young, thrash his sides while he is still small, Lest he become stubborn, disobey you, and leave you disconsolate.

13.verse: Discipline your son, make heavy his yoke, lest his folly humiliate you.

14.verse: Better a poor man strong and robust, than a rich man with wasted frame.

15.verse: More precious than gold is health and well-being, contentment of spirit than coral.

16.verse: No treasure greater than a healthy body; no happiness, than a joyful heart!

17.verse: Preferable is death to a bitter life, unending sleep to constant illness.

18.verse: Dainties set before one who cannot eat are like the offerings placed before a tomb.

19.verse: What good is an offering to an idol that can neither taste nor smell?

20.verse: So it is with the afflicted man who groans at the good things his eyes behold!

21.verse: Do not give in to sadness, torment not yourself with brooding;

22.verse: Gladness of heart is the very life of man, cheerfulness prolongs his days.

23.verse: Distract yourself, renew your courage, drive resentment far away from you; For worry has brought death to many, nor is there aught to be gained from resentment.

24.verse: Envy and anger shorten one's life, worry brings on premature old age.

25.verse: One who is cheerful and gay while at table benefits from his food.

annotations.1: [1-13] Sound discipline and careful education of children correct frivolity and stubbornness, prevent remorse and humiliation, and bring to parents lasting joy and delight, prestige among friends, jealousy of enemies, perpetuation and vindication of themselves through their offspring ( Sirach 30:1-6). Lack of discipline and overindulgence of children bring sorrow and disappointment, terror and grief ( Sirach 30:7-13).
annotations.2: [14-25] Health of mind and body and joy of heart are judged more precious than wealth ( Sirach 30:14-16); bitterness, constant illness and affliction more difficult to bear than death ( Sirach 30:17-20). Sadness, resentment, anxiety, envy and anger shorten . . . life; they should be dispelled by cheerfulness and gladness of heart, which help to prolong one's days ( Sirach 30:21-25)
annotations.3: [17] Preferable is death . . . constant illness: the true value of human suffering was revealed through the passion and death of Christ. It serves as reparation for sin, and when united with Christ's suffering, as merit for eternal life

1.verse: The Eternal is the judge of all things without exception; the LORD alone is just.

2.verse: Whom has he made equal to describing his works, and who can probe his mighty deeds?

3.verse: Who can measure his majestic power, or exhaust the tale of his mercies?

4.verse: One cannot lessen, nor increase, nor penetrate the wonders of the LORD.

5.verse: When a man ends he is only beginning, and when he stops he is still bewildered.

6.verse: What is man, of what worth is he? the good, the evil in him, what are these?

7.verse: The sum of a man's days is great if it reaches a hundred years:

8.verse: Like a drop of sea water, like a grain of sand, so are these few years among the days of eternity.

9.verse: That is why the LORD is patient with men and showers upon them his mercy.

10.verse: He sees and understands that their death is grievous, and so he forgives them all the more.

11.verse: Man may be merciful to his fellow man, but the LORD'S mercy reaches all flesh,

12.verse: Reproving, admonishing, teaching, as a shepherd guides his flock;

13.verse: Merciful to those who accept his guidance, who are diligent in his precepts.

14.verse: My son, to your charity add no reproach, nor spoil any gift by harsh words.

15.verse: Like dew that abates a burning wind, so does a word improve a gift.

16.verse: Sometimes the word means more than the gift; both are offered by a kindly man.

17.verse: Only a fool upbraids before giving; a grudging gift wears out the expectant eyes.

18.verse: Be informed before speaking; before sickness prepare the cure.

19.verse: Before you are judged, seek merit for yourself, and at the time of visitation you will have a ransom.

20.verse: Before you have fallen, humble yourself; when you have sinned, show repentance.

21.verse: Delay not to forsake sins, neglect it not till you are in distress.

22.verse: Let nothing prevent the prompt payment of your vows; wait not to fulfill them when you are dying.

23.verse: Before making a vow have the means to fulfill it; be not one who tries the LORD.

24.verse: Think of wrath and the day of death, the time of vengeance when he will hide his face.

25.verse: Remember the time of hunger in the time of plenty, poverty and want in the day of wealth.

26.verse: Between morning and evening the weather changes; before the LORD all things are fleeting.

27.verse: A wise man is circumspect in all things; when sin is rife he keeps himself from wrongdoing.

28.verse: Any learned man should make wisdom known, and he who attains to her should declare her praise;

29.verse: Those trained in her words must show their wisdom, dispensing sound proverbs like life-giving waters.

30.verse: Go not after your lusts, but keep your desires in check.

31.verse: If you satisfy your lustful appetites they will make you the sport of your enemies.

32.verse: Have no joy in the pleasures of a moment which bring on poverty redoubled;

33.verse: Become not a glutton and a winebibber with nothing in your purse.

annotations.1: [1-13] Not only are God's justice and power beyond man's understanding ( Sirach 18:1-5), his mercy also is boundless and surpasses all human compassion ( Sirach 18:6-13).
annotations.2: [14-27] The practice of charity is an art which avoids every offense to the recipient ( Sirach 18:14-18). Prudence directs the changing circumstances of daily life toward the attainment of its reward at the time of visitation, i.e., the day of reckoning ( Sirach 18:19-27)
annotations.3: [19] Merit . . . ransom: almsgiving is often portrayed in the Bible as a means of approach to the forgiving mercy of God. Cf Sirach 3:29-30; 29:11-12; Tobit 12:12-13; Daniel 4:24; Luke 16:9; Acts 10:31
annotations.4: [22-23] The usual object of a vow in Old Testament times was the offering of a bloody sacrifice
annotations.5: [28-29] A general statement on the teaching of wisdom, serving either as a conclusion to the preceding section or as an introduction to the following one. The neighbors of the wise man are regarded as the field into which he channels the waters of wisdom to encourage growth. Cf Sirach 24:28-31
annotations.6: [ 18:30- 19:4] Inordinate gratification of the senses makes a man unreasonable, the slave of passion, the sport of his enemies. In the end it destroys him physically and spiritually

1.verse: Valiant leader was JOSHUA, son of Nun, assistant to Moses in the prophetic office, Formed to be, as his name implies, the great savior of God's chosen ones, To punish the enemy and to win the inheritance for Israel.

2.verse: What glory was his when he raised his arm, to brandish his javelin against the city!

3.verse: And who could withstand him when he fought the battles of the LORD?

4.verse: Did he not by his power stop the sun, so that one day became two?

5.verse: He called upon the Most High God when his enemies beset him on all sides, And God Most High gave answer to him in hailstones of tremendous power,

6.verse: Which he rained down upon the hostile army till on the slope he destroyed the foe; That all the doomed nations might know that the LORD was watching over his people's battles. And because he was a devoted follower of God

7.verse: and in Moses' lifetime showed himself loyal, He and CALEB, son of Jephunneh, when they opposed the rebel assembly, Averted God's anger from the people and suppressed the wicked complaint -

8.verse: Because of this, they were the only two spared from the six hundred thousand infantry, To lead the people into their inheritance, the land flowing with milk and honey.

9.verse: And the strength he gave to Caleb remained with him even in his old age Till he won his way onto the summits of the land; his family too received an inheritance,

10.verse: That all the people of Jacob might know how good it is to be a devoted follower of the LORD.

11.verse: The JUDGES, too, each one of them, whose hearts were not deceived, Who did not abandon God: may their memory be ever blessed,

12.verse: Their bones return to life from their resting place, and their names receive fresh luster in their children!

13.verse: Beloved of his people, dear to his Maker, dedicated from his mother's womb, Consecrated to the LORD as a prophet, was SAMUEL, the judge and priest. At God's word he established the kingdom and anointed princes to rule the people.

14.verse: By the law of the LORD he judged the nation, when he visited the encampments of Jacob.

15.verse: As a trustworthy prophet he was sought out and his words proved him true as a seer.

16.verse: He, too, called upon God, and offered him a suckling lamb;

17.verse: Then the LORD thundered forth from heaven, and the tremendous roar of his voice was heard.

18.verse: He brought low the rulers of the enemy and destroyed all the lords of the Philistines.

19.verse: When Samuel approached the end of his life, he testified before the LORD and his anointed prince, "No bribe or secret gift have I taken from any man!" and no one dared gainsay him.

20.verse: Even when he lay buried, his guidance was sought; he made known to the king his fate, And from the grave he raised his voice as a prophet, to put an end to wickedness.

annotations.1: [1-6] Joshua, whose name means "the Lord is savior" ( Sirach 46:1), was the instrument through which God delivered his people in miraculous ways ( Sirach 46:2-6) by destroying their enemies, whose land he gave to the Israelites as an inheritance ( Sirach 46:1).
annotations.2: [3] The battles of the LORD: cf Joshua 6-10
annotations.3: [7-10] Caleb, who with Joshua advised Moses and the people in the desert to conquer Canaan, despite the counsel of their companion scouts and the rebellion of the people, merited to lead the Israelites of the succeeding generation into the Promised Land. Caleb in his old age received as his inheritance a portion of land which he himself had previously conquered; cf Joshua 15:13-14
annotations.4: [11-20] Of the Judges praised and blessed for their fidelity to God in opposing idolatry, Samuel, a man of spotless integrity, was the greatest ( Sirach 46:11-12, 19). He was judge of the entire nation, and was also a prophet and priest who through his sacrificial offering obtained victory over the Philistines. He established the kingdom, anointed kings ( Sirach 46:13-18), and even after his death foretold the king's fate and put an end to wickedness ( Sirach 46:20)

1.verse: The vengeful will suffer the LORD'S vengeance, for he remembers their sins in detail.

2.verse: Forgive your neighbor's injustice; then when you pray, your own sins will be forgiven.

3.verse: Should a man nourish anger against his fellows and expect healing from the LORD?

4.verse: Should a man refuse mercy to his fellows, yet seek pardon for his own sins?
