5.verse: If he who is but flesh cherishes wrath, who will forgive his sins?

6.verse: Remember your last days, set enmity aside; remember death and decay, and cease from sin!

7.verse: Think of the commandments, hate not your neighbor; of the Most High's covenant, and overlook faults.

8.verse: Avoid strife and your sins will be fewer, for a quarrelsome man kindles disputes,

9.verse: Commits the sin of disrupting friendship and sows discord among those at peace.

10.verse: The more wood, the greater the fire, the more underlying it, the fiercer the fight; The greater a man's strength, the sterner his anger, the greater his power, the greater his wrath.

11.verse: Pitch and resin make fires flare up, and insistent quarrels provoke bloodshed.

12.verse: If you blow upon a spark, it quickens into flame, if you spit on it, it dies out; yet both you do with your mouth!

13.verse: Cursed be gossips and the double-tongued, for they destroy the peace of many.

14.verse: A meddlesome tongue subverts many, and makes them refugees among the peoples; It destroys walled cities, and overthrows powerful dynasties.

15.verse: A meddlesome tongue can drive virtuous women from their homes and rob them of the fruit of their toil;

16.verse: Whoever heeds it has no rest, nor can he dwell in peace.

17.verse: A blow from a whip raises a welt, but a blow from the tongue smashes bones;

18.verse: Many have fallen by the edge of the sword, but not as many as by the tongue.

19.verse: Happy he who is sheltered from it, and has not endured its wrath; Who has not borne its yoke nor been fettered with its chain;

20.verse: For its yoke is a yoke of iron and its chains are chains of bronze!

21.verse: Dire is the death it inflicts, besides which even the nether world is a gain;

22.verse: It will not take hold among the just nor scorch them in its flame,

23.verse: But those who forsake the LORD will fall victims to it, as it burns among them unquenchably! It will hurl itself against them like a lion; like a panther, it will tear them to pieces.

24.verse: As you hedge round your vineyard with thorns, set barred doors over your mouth;

25.verse: As you seal up your silver and gold, so balance and weigh your words.

26.verse: Take care not to slip by your tongue and fall victim to your foe waiting in ambush.

annotations.1: [12-26] Further treatment of sins of the tongue and their havoc; cf Sirach 5:12- 6:1; 19:5-16; 20:17-25; 23:7-15. Gossips and the double-tongued destroy domestic peace ( Sirach 28:12-16). The whip, the sword, chains, even the nether world, are not so cruel as the suffering inflicted by an evil tongue ( Sirach 28:17-21). Not the just but those who forsake the LORD are victims of their evil tongues ( Sirach 28:22, 23). Therefore, guard your mouth and tongue as you would guard treasure against an enemy ( Sirach 28:24-26).

1.verse: But of these things be not ashamed, lest you sin through human respect:

2.verse: Of the law of the Most High and his precepts, or of the sentence to be passed upon the sinful;

3.verse: Of sharing the expenses of a business or a journey, or of dividing an inheritance or property;

4.verse: Of accuracy of scales and balances, or of tested measures and weights;

5.verse: Of acquiring much or little, or of bargaining in dealing with a merchant; Of constant training of children, or of beating the sides of a disloyal servant;

6.verse: Of a seal to keep an erring wife at home, or of a lock placed where there are many hands;

7.verse: Of numbering every deposit, or of recording all that is given or received;

8.verse: Of chastisement of the silly and the foolish, or of the aged and infirm answering for wanton conduct. Thus you will be truly cautious and recognized by all men as discreet.

9.verse: A daughter is a treasure that keeps her father wakeful, and worry over her drives away rest: Lest she pass her prime unmarried, or when she is married, lest she be disliked;

10.verse: While unmarried, lest she be seduced, or, as a wife, lest she prove unfaithful; Lest she conceive in her father's home, or be sterile in that of her husband.

11.verse: Keep a close watch on your daughter, lest she make you the sport of your enemies, A byword in the city, a reproach among the people, an object of derision in public gatherings. See that there is no lattice in her room, no place that overlooks the approaches to the house.

12.verse: Let her not parade her charms before men, or spend her time with married women;

13.verse: For just as moths come from garments, so harm to women comes from women:

14.verse: Better a man's harshness than a woman's indulgence, and a frightened daughter than any disgrace.

15.verse: Now will I recall God's works; what I have seen, I will describe. At God's word were his works brought into being; they do his will as he has ordained for them.

16.verse: As the rising sun is clear to all, so the glory of the LORD fills all his works;

17.verse: Yet even God's holy ones must fail in recounting the wonders of the LORD, Though God has given these, his hosts, the strength to stand firm before his glory.

18.verse: He plumbs the depths and penetrates the heart; their innermost being he understands. The Most High possesses all knowledge, and sees from of old the things that are to come:

19.verse: He makes known the past and the future, and reveals the deepest secrets.

20.verse: No understanding does he lack; no single thing escapes him.

21.verse: Perennial is his almighty wisdom; he is from all eternity one and the same,

22.verse: With nothing added, nothing taken away; no need of a counselor for him!

23.verse: How beautiful are all his works! even to the spark and the fleeting vision!

24.verse: The universe lives and abides forever; to meet each need, each creature is preserved.

25.verse: All of them differ, one from another, yet none of them has he made in vain, For each in turn, as it comes, is good; can one ever see enough of their splendor?

annotations.1: [9-14] The author considers a daughter to be a source of anxiety to her father, lest she fail to marry, or be seduced, or lest, marrying, she be disliked, prove unfaithful, or find herself sterile ( Sirach 42:9-10). He is advised to keep a close watch on her at home, and on her companionship while abroad, lest he suffer on her account among the people ( Sirach 42:11-14).
annotations.2: [ 42:15- 43:35] These verses comprise a new section. In them the author contemplates God's power, beauty and goodness as manifested in the mighty work of creating and preserving the universe ( Sirach 42:15-17, 23, 25; 43:1-27), his omniscience ( Sirach 42:18-20), his perfect wisdom ( Sirach 42:21-22), his eternity ( Sirach 42:24). The conclusion is a fervent hymn of praise ( Sirach 43:28-33). Cf Sirach 16:22- 18:13

1.verse: Come to our aid, O God of the universe, and put all the nations in dread of you!

2.verse: Raise your hand against the heathen, that they may realize your power.

3.verse: As you have used us to show them your holiness, so now use them to show us your glory.

4.verse: Thus they will know, as we know, that there is no God but you.

5.verse: Give new signs and work new wonders; show forth the splendor of your right hand and arm;

6.verse: Rouse your anger, pour out wrath, humble the enemy, scatter the foe.

7.verse: Hasten the day, bring on the time;

9.verse: crush the heads of the hostile rulers.

8.verse: Let raging fire consume the fugitive, and your people's oppressors meet destruction.

10.verse: Gather all the tribes of Jacob, that they may inherit the land as of old,

11.verse: Show mercy to the people called by your name; Israel, whom you named your first-born.

12.verse: Take pity on your holy city, Jerusalem, your dwelling place.

13.verse: Fill Zion with your majesty, your temple with your glory.

14.verse: Give evidence of your deeds of old; fulfill the prophecies spoken in your name,

15.verse: Reward those who have hoped in you, and let your prophets be proved true.

16.verse: Hear the prayer of your servants, for you are ever gracious to your people;

17.verse: Thus it will be known to the very ends of the earth that you are the eternal God.

18.verse: The throat can swallow any food, yet some foods are more agreeable than others;

19.verse: As the palate tests meat by its savor, so does a keen mind insincere words.

20.verse: A deceitful character causes grief, but an experienced man can turn the tables on him.

21.verse: Though any man may be accepted as a husband, yet one girl will be more suitable than another:

22.verse: A woman's beauty makes her husband's face light up, for it surpasses all else that charms the eye;

23.verse: And if, besides, her speech is kindly, his lot is beyond that of mortal men.

24.verse: A wife is her husband's richest treasure, a helpmate, a steadying column.

25.verse: A vineyard with no hedge will be overrun; a man with no wife becomes a homeless wanderer.

26.verse: Who will trust an armed band that shifts from city to city?

27.verse: Or a man who has no nest, but lodges where night overtakes him?

annotations.1: [1-17] Making an act of faith and hope in the supreme Lord of the universe, the author begs God to continue manifesting his holiness and mercy through Israel, his people ( Sirach 36:1-3, 10-13), and his power and justice through the punishment of the nations ( Sirach 36:2, 5-9), that all the earth may acknowledge him the eternal God ( Sirach 36:4, 14-17).
annotations.2: [ 36:18- 37:15] In the choice of wife, friend or associate, experience is a discerner of character ( Sirach 36:18-21). Beauty and kindly speech make a woman desirable as wife ( Sirach 36:22-24). The good wife becomes her husband's richest treasure, his helpmate in establishing his household ( Sirach 36:24-27). A true friend fights for his comrade and shares his spoils with him ( Sirach 37:5-6); a false one deceives and abandons him in time of need ( Sirach 37:1-4). A true counselor and associate should be sought among those who keep the commandments, not among those who break them and seek their own advantage ( Sirach 37:7-12). In all things pray to God for light and follow conscience ( Sirach 37:13-15)

1.verse: Hold the physician in honor, for he is essential to you, and God it was who established his profession.

2.verse: From God the doctor has his wisdom, and the king provides for his sustenance.

3.verse: His knowledge makes the doctor distinguished, and gives him access to those in authority.

4.verse: God makes the earth yield healing herbs which the prudent man should not neglect;

5.verse: Was not the water sweetened by a twig that men might learn his power?

6.verse: He endows men with the knowledge to glory in his mighty works,

7.verse: Through which the doctor eases pain and the druggist prepares his medicines;

8.verse: Thus God's creative work continues without cease in its efficacy on the surface of the earth.

9.verse: My son, when you are ill, delay not, but pray to God, who will heal you:

10.verse: Flee wickedness; let your hands be just, cleanse your heart of every sin;

11.verse: Offer your sweet-smelling oblation and petition, a rich offering according to your means.

12.verse: Then give the doctor his place lest he leave; for you need him too.

13.verse: There are times that give him an advantage,

14.verse: and he too beseeches God That his diagnosis may be correct and his treatment bring about a cure.

15.verse: He who is a sinner toward his Maker will be defiant toward the doctor.

16.verse: My son, shed tears for one who is dead with wailing and bitter lament; As is only proper, prepare the body, absent not yourself from his burial:

17.verse: Weeping bitterly, mourning fully, pay your tribute of sorrow, as he deserves,

18.verse: One or two days, to prevent gossip; then compose yourself after your grief,

19.verse: For grief can bring on an extremity and heartache destroy one's health.

20.verse: Turn not your thoughts to him again; cease to recall him; think rather of the end.

21.verse: Recall him not, for there is no hope of his return; it will not help him, but will do you harm.

22.verse: Remember that his fate will also be yours; for him it was yesterday, for you today.

23.verse: With the departed dead, let memory fade; rally your courage, once the soul has left.

24.verse: The scribe's profession increases his wisdom; whoever is free from toil can become a wise man.

25.verse: How can he become learned who guides the plow, who thrills in wielding the goad like a lance, Who guides the ox and urges on the bullock, and whose every concern is for cattle?

26.verse: His care is for plowing furrows, and he keeps a watch on the beasts in the stalls.

27.verse: So with every engraver and designer who, laboring night and day, Fashions carved seals, and whose concern is to vary the pattern. His care is to produce a vivid impression, and he keeps watch till he finishes his design.

28.verse: So with the smith standing near his anvil, forging crude iron. The heat from the fire sears his flesh, yet he toils away in the furnace heat. The clang of the hammer deafens his ears, His eyes are fixed on the tool he is shaping. His care is to finish his work, and he keeps watch till he perfects it in detail.

29.verse: So with the potter sitting at his labor, revolving the wheel with his feet. He is always concerned for his products, and turns them out in quantity.

30.verse: With his hands he molds the clay, and with his feet softens it. His care is for proper coloring, and he keeps watch on the fire of his kiln.

31.verse: All these men are skilled with their hands, each one an expert at his own task;

32.verse: Without them no city could be lived in, and wherever they stay, they need not hunger.

33.verse: They do not occupy the judge's bench, nor are they prominent in the assembly; They set forth no decisions or judgments, nor are they found among the rulers;

34.verse: Yet they maintain God's ancient handiwork, and their concern is for exercise of their skill.

annotations.1: [1-15] The profession of medicine comes from God, who makes the earth yield healing herbs and gives the physician knowledge of their virtue ( Sirach 38:1-8). In illness the sick man should cleanse his soul from sin and petition God for help through an offering of sacrifice; the physician, too, does well to invoke God that he may understand the illness and apply the proper remedy ( Sirach 38:9-14). The sinner, in contrast, defies both his Maker and the doctor ( Sirach 38:15).
annotations.2: [16-23] A period of mourning for the deceased and care for their burial is becoming ( Sirach 38:16-18). But grief should not be excessive, for it neither helps the dead, who cannot return, nor fails to harm the living. The mourner's own end will quickly follow, and the time to prepare for it is now ( Sirach 38:19-23)
annotations.3: [ 38:24- 39:11] More excellent than the useful service of craftsmen-farmer, engraver, smith, potter ( Sirach 38:25-34)-is the profession of the scribe ( Sirach 39:24), who studies and meditates on the law of the Most High, seeks him in prayer of thanksgiving, petition and repentance for sin ( Sirach 39:1, 6, 7), explores the wisdom of the past and present, travels abroad to observe the conduct of many peoples, and attends rulers and great men. Through the spirit of understanding granted by God, he will show forth his wisdom to the glory of God's law, gaining renown for generations to come ( Sirach 39:2-5, 8-11)
